ORAL ANSWERS TO QUESTIONS

PUBLIC AND RESTRUCTURED HOSPITALS

(Prices for treatment)

    1.  Mr Siew Kum Hong asked the Minister for Health (a) how do public and restructured hospitals set their prices for treatments; and (b) why and how were they able to reduce their prices for various treatments without compromising the quality of patient care or length of stay, after the Ministry began publishing the bills for such treatments across different hospitals.

      The Minister for Health (Mr Khaw Boon Wan):  Mr Speaker, Sir, public hospitals set their treatment prices based on their operating cost and the prescribed subsidy policy.


     After my Ministry published the hospital bill sizes for the 70 most common medical conditions, the hospitals were then able to more systematically compare their cost performance with the others.  This has allowed the cost-outliers to review why their patients ended up with larger hospital bills.


     A significant factor is the way doctors undertake their clinical practices and treatment processes.  For instance, there are several ways to treat patients requiring gall bladder surgery.  One hospital used to admit such patients for pre-surgery preparation a day before surgery.  However, most hospitals prepare their patients on an outpatient basis and

Column: 1794

admitted them only on the day of surgery.  This avoids one day of hospitalisation and led to cost-savings for both hospitals and patients.

 

     There are also ways to save cost for patients by using more cost-effective but equivalent substitutes in the treatment process.  Staying on the example of gall bladder surgery, patients used to be given antibiotics through intravenous drips until their discharge a few days later.  Now, they take the antibiotics in pill form from the day of surgery, which cuts costs as intravenous antibiotics are many times more expensive.


     The publication of hospital bill sizes has pushed our public hospitals to compete to bring better healthcare services at lower cost and also to learn best clinical practices from one another.

 

    Mr Siew Kum Hong (Nominated Member):  Sir, I am glad to hear that this practice of publishing different prices for treatment has reduced the cost of healthcare for the public.  I would like to ask the Minister what are the other areas in which this can be done so as to further reduce the cost faced by the public.

      Mr Khaw Boon Wan:  The key is more information - better, relevant and timely information - because healthcare, as we know, is highly complicated.  On the other hand, you can also have information overload if we publish too much information and nobody would read it.  So you have to be able to, in a smart manner, pick up the key trends and then publish them in a way which people can use and understand.

  
    Frankly speaking, I doubt patients go to our website and check before they decide to go to hospitals because very few are as well-informed.  But I do expect their referring doctors, whether they be GPs or polyclinic doctors, who understand the subject better, to regularly look at our

Column: 1795

updates so that when they have a patient in front of them requiring specialist attention, they know which hospital and which doctor to refer to, in order to get the best value for money on behalf of their patients.  That is why, besides bill sizes, I also publish information like waiting time and queuing time.  The whole idea is to give more information to the marketplace, to the players, so that we can help level the patient load and along the way, hopefully, it will be better service all round.

Column: 1795

HUMAN ORGAN TRANSPLANT IN SINGAPORE

(Update on status)

    2.  Dr Lim Wee Kiak asked the Minister for Health (a) if he will provide an update on the status of organ transplant in Singapore; (b) how many people have benefited from the Human Organ Transplant Act since the opt out system was introduced  in 1987; and (c) whether there will be a review on the legalisation of sale of human organs by his Ministry.

     Mr Khaw Boon Wan:  Sir, the first kidney transplant was carried out in Singapore in 1970.  This was 37 years ago.  As at the end of last year, 1,778 kidney, 83 liver, 27 heart, 7 lung and 2,356 cornea transplants have been done in Singapore.


     The Human Organ Transplant Act (HOTA) was enacted in 1987. So it was 20 years ago.  From 1987 until the middle of 2004, 222 patients with kidney failure have benefited from cadaveric kidney transplants under HOTA, giving an average of 13 patients per year.  This was an improvement as prior to HOTA, cadaveric kidney transplantation only averaged five per year.  So before HOTA, only five lives were saved each year.  After HOTA, it almost tripled to 13.  In the middle of 2004, HOTA was amended to cover the liver, the heart and the cornea,

Column: 1796

and to include all causes of death.  I took this Bill through in this House and I was glad for the full support from the House.  From then until the end of last year, 103 kidney patients benefited from cadaveric transplants under the amended HOTA - an average of 41 patients per year, which is a significant increase.  So before HOTA, five per year; now, 41 per year - more than an eight-fold increase.  So we are saving lives, just for kidneys, almost one per week.  In addition, 115 patients have benefited from 11 cadaveric livers, 10 hearts and 94 corneas.  HOTA is therefore a very important policy in saving lives.


     Nevertheless, there remains a shortage of organs for transplantation.  At the beginning of this month, there were 541 patients on the waiting list for kidney, 10 for liver, 2 for lung and 1 for heart.  Each year, some patients die while waiting for an organ.


     Society as a whole has an interest to increase the supply of donated organs so that such premature deaths can be avoided or reduced.  The question is how to achieve such an outcome.  On and off, there have been suggestions that organs be traded, ie, be bought and sold, to address the issue of organ shortage.  Recently, the idea has again generated much debate among Singaporeans.  Some support the concept, citing the effectiveness of such a market mechanism in increasing the supply.  However, even from a purely practical point of view, the matter is not so simple. Thus, we have a voluntary blood donation, but not sales of human blood, because allowing sales of human blood encourages the wrong sort of people to come forward.  Furthermore, many people, in Singapore and elsewhere, instinctively find the idea of trading human organs degrading and repulsive.  Organ trading is not purely an utilitarian issue, but also one that raises very difficult ethical problems. One of these is its likely impact on the poor, both as donors and recipients.

Column: 1797


     That is why hardly any country in the world has legalised organ trading, although a grey market often exists.  We will continue to monitor developments in other countries, including the feasibility of ethical trading.  This is a term used by some people, thinking that trading of organs can be done in an ethical manner.  But how is it going to be operationalised has yet to be seen.  However, as these difficult problems are not likely to be resolved soon, the Ministry has no plan to change our rule.

     Dr Lim Wee Kiak (Sembawang):  Sir, I would like to ask the Minister to elaborate or provide us some details on a recent unpleasant commotion that happened between the family members of a brain-dead patient as well as the authorities in one of our public hospitals a few weeks ago. I am wondering what measures will the Ministry be taking to prevent such an occurrence in the future.

     Mr Khaw Boon Wan:  Dr Lim works in the hospital and he knows that one of the most difficult tasks in running a hospital is to convey bad news, particularly of premature death or sudden death, to family members.  But I think more difficult than this task is telling the family members that their loved one has died, the brain has died, and that the organs can be used to save a few lives and that we are going to do so.  It is not the easiest of things to do. Very rarely do we have family members who come forward and say, "Yes.  Please proceed."


     Fortunately, the vast majority of family members are understanding and they accepted the sudden death and they try to compensate for the sudden loss by knowing that, at least, the death will now be able to save a few lives.  But occasionally, we do get family members who are probably traumatised by the sudden death, becoming pretty aggressive

Column: 1798

and, sometimes, even abusive.  But we try our best to explain, be as patient as we can and as compassionate as we can.  But the bottomline is that we need to be firm with this opting out policy and respect the wishes of the dead that they had not opted out of HOTA.  HOTA was fully explained.  Of course, we will continue to periodically explain it. People have a choice to opt out and if they do not opt out, we assume that they must have had no objection if, upon sudden death, to have their organs used to save lives. It will be good for them and for society at large because if you try to look it from the donor's point of view, do not forget that there are a few hundreds on the waiting list.  It is often the luck of the draw.  You never know which side you will be on.  Will you be a possible donor or a possible recipient?  If everybody opted out, then of course, the possibility of saving lives and the opportunity to do so will be reduced.


     The key point about our HOTA policy is that it is not compulsory organ donation. We respect the individual's decision.  If they want to opt out, no question is asked and we facilitate it.  And we respect that because who are we to say that it is right or wrong of them to opt in or to opt out?  But we have a job to try to explain to Singaporeans as often and as thoroughly as we can to think about that, upon death, the body is otherwise useless but you can still perform a useful role to save a few lives.  And it has happened a few thousand times in the last many years that we have had HOTA.


    But we understand that, yes, it is traumatic experience for the family and we try to be as patient and flexible as we can.  In this instance, it was rather unfortunate.  Of course, the sudden death was traumatising to the family but they knew that the patient had died.  They did ask for more time, and often, we allow that.  In this instance, the family said, "Please do not go in yet.

 

 


Give us another 24 hours", so that they can perform their

Column: 1799

various Taoist rituals.  The hospital was flexible and allowed them an extension but explained to them that there was a time limit, because when all the cells had died, there was nothing to talk about in terms of organ donation.  Indeed, in this instance, after the 24 hours' extension was given, the liver which was useful was no longer useful.  I forgot now how many people are on the liver waiting queue.  We prepared the patients and they were waiting for the operation.  Unfortunately, we had to go in and say, "Sorry, the liver is now useless."  But the kidneys were still useful, and there were two patients being prepared next door.  At the appointed time, unfortunately, the family said, "We want more time."  But the organs were deteriorating, and if the hospital were to allow more time, then even the kidneys would become useless.


     These are the circumstances behind this incident.  I do not want to go into further gory details because it may not be fair to the family.  I for one can fully understand what sort of trauma they were going through.  This person was only 42 years old - sudden death.  It is not easy to be put in that kind of situation.  Let me come back to the basic point - respect the wishes of the dead.  At 42, that means he was around 21 or 22 when HOTA was introduced in this House.  I remember there was widespread public debate.  He was an educated man and I am sure he was fully aware of HOTA and the fact that he did not opt out means that he wanted to save lives in the event of any sudden death, and I think we should respect his wishes.  In this instance, I think it is good for the family that at least two lives and a cornea transplant were able to take place.


     We will learn from this to train our staff to be even more sensitive and compassionate in our communication process.  But the bottomline is, it is a difficult task to do.

Column: 1800

     Dr Lim Wee Kiak: Sir, I want to thank the Minister for the comprehensive explanation.  I guess that the most important issue is that of public education.  I am wondering whether the Ministry will consider embarking on a publicity campaign to explain the HOTA again.  They will have to do it probably in a recurrent manner, almost like a "Celebrate Organ Donation Day" every year.  I hope the Ministry can consider this.

     Mr Khaw Boon Wan:   The answer is yes.  We will definitely do so.  Our communication experts advise us that this is not the time to re-start.  Let the emotions calm down first.  But certainly we will have to do it regularly.  For Singaporeans turning 21, they receive brochures on HOTA.  We batch it twice a year and send out a lot of materials.  I know this because my daughter received them when she turned 21.  So there are programmes of that kind.  But it is a morbid subject.  And I know Singaporeans, the majority of them will say, "I don't want to think about it."  But from this incident, let us all be wiser after this and learn from this.  And bear in mind that it is your wish; we will respect it.  But think about this, that upon death, the body is otherwise useless.  But it is not that useless, it can still save lives.  I think saving lives is still priority.

Column: 1800

ASEAN FRAMEWORK AGREEMENT ON SERVICES

     3.  Ms Lee Bee Wah asked the Minister for Trade and Industry (a) if he will provide an update on the status of the arrangements on Professional Engineering, Architectural Services and Construction Services under the ASEAN Framework Agreement on Services; (b) how have these service agreements translated into actual practice for Singapore’s engineering and construction industries; and (c) how did the Ministry get feedback from local industry players before it entered into

Column: 1801

discussions to work out these service agreements.

     The Minister of State for Trade and Industry (Mr Lee Yi Shyan) (for the Minister for Trade and Industry): Mr Speaker, Sir, there are several Mutual Recognition Arrangements (MRA) negotiations that we are involved in under the ambit of the ASEAN Framework Agreement on Services (AFAS).  These are MRAs on Engineering Services, Architectural Services, and Land Surveying Services, among others.  ASEAN signed an MRA on Engineering Services in December 2005, while the other MRAs are currently under active negotiations. 

 

     Upon the signing of the MRA, we are required to establish the agreed structures, such as the monitoring committee to develop process and maintain an ASEAN Chartered Engineers' Register and the ASEAN Chartered Professional Engineering Coordinating Committee to assess and confer the title of ASEAN Chartered Professional Engineer.  This will then allow our engineers to be recognised as an ASEAN Chartered Professional Engineer and work in collaboration with designated Professional Engineers of the host ASEAN countries without having to undertake the usual domestic registration requirements.

 

     To date, there are five ASEAN members, namely, Malaysia, Philippines, Singapore, Thailand and Vietnam, participating in the Engineering Services MRA.  Laos had recently indicated their interest in becoming the sixth member.

 

     Members are currently in the process of setting up the agreed structures to implement the MRA.  This process is expected to take another six months.  Upon completion, the MRA on Engineering Services is expected to enable our qualified engineers to move freely

Column: 1802

between Singapore and the various ASEAN countries.

 

     For ASEAN, our top priority is to enhance economic integration among member countries towards achieving the ASEAN Economic Community by 2015.  MRAs seek to achieve this by facilitating the movement of skilled professionals across borders.  The ASEAN MRA on Engineering Services, for instance, creates a regional platform for the mutual recognition of registration requirements for foreign engineers.  In the past, foreign engineers had to be registered with the local regulatory authorities and meet various requirements before they were permitted to provide engineering services in the respective ASEAN countries. 

 

     In our FTA negotiations, whether within ASEAN or otherwise, MTI periodically conducts consultations with our partner agencies, business associations, professional bodies, and companies to identify their interests, targets, and their requirements with regard to a particular market.  In some instances, our professional bodies, such as the Professional Engineers Board, Land Surveyors Board and Board of Architects, even participate in negotiations alongside with MTI's staff in external meetings.  This is to ensure that the industry's inputs are fully incorporated into the negotiations with external bodies.  MTI would undertake periodic consultations with these professional bodies and others which Members of this House might recommend, to ensure that our industry interests are maintained and that these MRAs meet the primary objective of facilitating trade and services.

     Ms Lee Bee Wah (Ang Mo Kio):  Sir, I would like to thank the Minister of State for the comprehensive briefing.  I would like to recommend the Minister of State to involve more industry players, such as the Institution of Engineers and the Singapore

Column: 1803

Institute of Architects, in the consultation and negotiation processes.

     Mr Lee Yi Shyan: Mr Speaker, Sir, I agree with Ms Lee's recommendation.

SUNGEI BULOH WETLAND RESERVE

(Flotsam pollution)

     4.  Ms Lee Bee Wah asked the Minister for the Environment and Water Resources (a) whether his Ministry is able to trace the source of the flotsam and other rubbish that may have come from the Johor Straits that has been polluting the Sungei Buloh Wetland Reserve; and (b) if there are other options to solving this problem on a permanent basis apart from just removing the floating debris.

     The Senior Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for the Environment and Water Resources (Dr Amy Khor Lean Suan) (for the Minister for the Environment and Water Resources):  Mr Speaker, Sir, the PUB has installed gratings in the drains and canals that lead to the Sungei Buloh Wetland Reserve, to prevent litter and debris that may be present in our inland water courses from landing on the Reserve. However, the Reserve, being located along the Straits of Johor, will continue to face the problem of flotsam being washed onto its shores from time to time. 

 

     NParks, which manages and maintains the Reserve, will study ways to minimise the amount of flotsam that is washed onto the Reserve from the Straits of Johor.  Nonetheless, as flotsam can originate from various sources, including litter that ends up in waterways, we need the cooperation of the community in keeping public areas clean.

 

     Ms Lee Bee Wah: Sir, I would like to ask the Senior Parliamentary Secretary whether there is any other action or any further plan that can be done to further improve the situation.

Column: 1804

     Dr Amy Khor Lean Suan: Sir, currently, NParks carries out twice weekly coastal cleaning of the Reserve, whilst within the Reserve, it is cleaned daily.  In addition, other schools, community groups and volunteers also assist in the coastal clean up of the Reserve, especially during weekends, public and school holidays.  As I have noted earlier in my reply, NParks is currently also exploring other ways to minimise the amount of flotsam that is washed onto the Reserve. Notwithstanding this effort, I think it is important to reiterate again that we need to have the full cooperation of the community to keep public areas clean, so that we can enjoy these nature reserves, parks and other public areas.

Column: 1804

CLEANING CONTRACTORS IN PRIVATE HOUSING ESTATES

(Job scope)

     5.  Ms Lee Bee Wah asked the Minister for the Environment and Water Resources (a) what is the job scope of contractors responsible for the cleaning of roads, pavements and drains in private housing estates; (b) what is the frequency of such cleaning; and (c) who monitors this work.

 

 

     Dr Amy Khor Lean Suan (for the Minister for the Environment and Water Resources): Mr Speaker, Sir, my Ministry employs contractors to clean private housing estates.  The cleaning contractors sweep the roads and remove litter from the pavements, footpaths, grass verges, bus-stops and other open public areas in the estates.  Cleaning is carried out at least twice a week.  Some estates which are more heavily littered are cleaned more frequently, including everyday if necessary.  In addition, litter bins are emptied daily.  Contractors are also engaged to remove litter and leaves from drains in private housing estates.  All drains are cleaned at least once a week, with the more heavily littered drains cleaned up to three times a week.

Column: 1805

 

     In addition to checks by ground supervisors of the cleaning contractors, NEA and PUB officers conduct regular audit checks to ensure that the cleaning works are carried out satisfactorily according to schedule. Residents with feedback may contact NEA or PUB.  They may also contact the cleaning contractor in charge of their estates.  Cleaning contractors for private estates have also informed residents of the cleaning schedules for their estates.

 

     Other than the cleaning contractors, NEA's workmen also clean some of the private estates in Singapore.  These workmen are supervised by NEA environmental health officers.

 

     Ms Lee Bee Wah: Sir, I definitely agree that the rubbish is cleaned every day but certainly not the road pavements.  In fact, I have pictures taken more than two weeks ago and until today, some of the rubbish is still there.  Sir, I would like to know whether the Ministry is going to tighten up the audit process, as we are paying the contractors for works not done, and this is a very common complaint in the private estates.

     Dr Amy Khor Lean Suan: Sir, currently, there are two levels of checks, as I have noted earlier.  Firstly, the cleaning companies deploy their ground supervisors to monitor the performance of these workmen for the areas under their care.  On top of this, the NEA officers also conduct daily audits to monitor the performance of these cleaning companies to ensure that they keep to the cleaning schedules and their workmen deliver the service satisfactorily.  In fact, our NEA ground officers also regularly review how frequently an area needs to be cleaned taking into account, of course, the volume of pedestrian traffic, how heavily littered the area is as well as the volume of leaf fall.  So, if necessary, they can require the

Column: 1806

cleaning contractors to clean the area more frequently.  Normally, as I said, it is cleaned twice a week but they could ask the cleaning contractors to clean three times or even every day.  This is how we actually monitor.  In fact, we have also asked the cleaning contractors to inform the residents of their cleaning schedules as well as cleaning frequency and to update the residents of this information once every six months, so that the residents can give us more meaningful and timely feedback.

     Order read for Resumption of Debate on Question [15th February, 2007].

     Question again proposed.

 

Column: 1807

 

 

     The Senior Minister of State for Foreign Affairs (Mr Zainul Abidin Rasheed): Mr Speaker, Sir, thank you for allowing me to speak on the Budget.  I rise in support of the Budget.

 

     After the speeches made yesterday, many would have felt that there is not much left to say. Practically everyone yesterday said "Aye", even Opposition Member Mr Low Thia Khiang, his comments on the GST notwithstanding. 

 

     First the celebrations. Many, inside and outside the House, have described the February 15th Budget as an early ang bao. Yes, Singaporeans deserve the big red ang bao, and, if I may add, Xin Nian Kuai Le and Gong Xi Fa Cai.

 

     Sir, yesterday, Mayor Amy Khor mentioned that some Singaporeans considered this Budget as "made in heaven". This reminds me about a Chinese belief that they need to please the Kitchen God with sweet goodies to avoid being  bad-mouthed by the Gods.  It seems that our Second Minister of Finance -  some might consider him the  God of Prosperity - has done the reverse and provided the goodies for his followers to be happy about. Thus, you can see how much sweet words have flooded yesterday's  session.

If you were to visit Eunos before the Chinese New Year, you will see, for example, we have converted an old marketplace into a nursery and, in fact, the buzz, the spirit and the feeling were so good that all residents enjoyed the opportunity.  Even the Bougainvillea flowers which we all normally see in red, pink or purple, there are actually so many of them with multi-colours - just to show how happy they are.  But we will also remember that the Bougainvillea is not

Column: 1808

just about colours, it is also about resilience.  It is a plant that, I think, many of you must have noticed that we planted along the ECP on the approach to the airport, is really very resilient and it can withstand harsh weather conditions.  So, we want our people to enjoy the colours but at the same time to be resilient too.  This is what our Budget is all about.

 

    Prior to this, during CCC and other grassroots meetings in Eunos, there was much concern raised about many issues, including cost of living, cost of healthcare, transport and employment. While all that has been fed - including the Workfare Income Supplement for low-income workers, CPF restoration, corporate tax cut and a generous offset package  to cushion the impact of the GST - are welcomed, there are still holes that need filling. This I know, especially if I use my experience working at the North East CDC.

 

    While the CDCs started off basically as a tool for bonding and social cohesion, before long, they moved to become important vehicles to help the needy. With the support of MOM and WDA and MCYS, and with feedback from the ground and lessons from how inadequate some of the earlier measures were, the CDCs now can perform their job more confidently.

 

     With your indulgence, Sir, allow me to cite the approach taken by the North East CDC to reflect the route we took and how we have moved up the ladder to make Singaporeans realise the importance of Workfare as a way out and for the future. When the economy slowed down, the North East CDC introduced what we call JAB, ie, to combine both jobs and bonding as our priorities. Realising that

Column: 1809

there were serious mindset problems in facing the challenges of globalisation and economic restructuring, we felt that jobs alone were not sufficient as workers were not ready to benefit from the new job opportunities. We then went on to introduce what we call JELL, or Jobs, Employability and Life-Long Learning, as a new thrust. Training and retraining was of prime concern. Now we call our programmes BCG, or Bonding, Care and Gain. In short, to give our fellow Singaporeans a boost for their efforts to continue to be relevant in today’s market and globalised world, we need to show care while we galvanise the support of the grassroots and the other better-off Singaporeans to help and bond too.

 

     I relate all these just to emphasise that help is not just about short-term programmes. We have to continue to be nimble and adjust as we go along. The Government has done so, and this Budget proves so, but Singaporeans, especially the low-income workers, cannot afford to see the wood for the trees.

Workfare is a short-term measure to help workers during the difficult times as they train and retrain and make themselves more employable and enjoy better and more sustainable salaries for themselves and their children.

 

     Fortunately for us, Sir, more and more Singaporeans - and this experience I see at the CDC - realise this. Compared to the first six months when we first introduced the assistance programmes, Singaporeans are now better prepared to stay focused on the long term and understand that these are short-term measures and that they would have to help themselves in the long term. Of course, there are those who still refuse to change and even abuse the programmes, but they are being identified and given help in changing their mindsets.

 

Column: 1810

     This is where the Government can do more to provide the resources for more people, especially at the grassroots level, to be trained to help out. MCYS has announced more funds for capacity building at the grassroots level and we hope that more grassroots and community leaders would respond to the call of many helping hands.

 

    Having said that, Sir, may I now turn to what Minister Tharman said about globalisation. I quote: "Our prospects have never been better. The key is globalisation."  We all agree.  However, we also realise that globalisation is a very big word. I am not sure how many of our fellow Singaporeans, especially those from the low income groups, understand that.

 

    This debate is a good opportunity to try make more people understand this phenomenon. The debate notwithstanding, I am glad that the Prime Minister would be having a post-Budget dialogue with grassroots leaders too to ensure that they understand not only the goodies but, more importantly, the fundamentals behind our policies and what globalisation means for Singapore.

 

     There is need for more of the message to be understood on the ground. I understand that MOF also encourages such dialogues at the ground level to reach out to as many Singaporeans as possible. This is indeed to be encouraged and I urge more Singaporeans to use such opportunities to better understand not only the goodies in the Budget but also what globalisation and its challenges are all about. It is not just about working and opportunities overseas but its impact locally, especially in terms of what it takes to be relevant, what skills do we need, what training and retraining do we need to continue to be employable.  Be they the types of jobs available, the importance of immigration - this is one area some Members had spoken about

Column: 1811

yesterday, and if not carefully handled and properly understood could even bring about problems in terms of cohesion in our society - and what new colours competition will take as we face globalisation.

 

     In short, we have to go global. And only if we understand its challenges do we avoid any Singaporean being left behind. The last thing we want is that while more and more Singaporeans benefit from going global, a section of the society, especially the low income, lags behind and, worse, feel marginalised.  If we understand those challenges, then it should also make us understand why we need the GST and its hike too.  Do not get too taxed by the GST debate but instead see it as a formula for us to Grow Strong Together (GST).

 

     Before I end, Sir, allow me to say a few words in Malay.

 

     (In Malay):  [For vernacular speech, please refer to Appendix A *.]  Mr Speaker, much has been said about this Budget. It is creative, has a long-term view and is generous.  For me, the Budget can be described as something which is considerate and humanitarian (berhati perut).   I say so because it not only covers programmes that can help the lower income group especially, but more importantly so that we can understand what is really the essence and the philosophy behind this Budget, the need to have long-term measures, whether in terms of understanding the need for GST, the reduction in corporate tax or the programmes to assist our workers in getting training and retraining and to prepare them for the challenges of what we call "globalisation".


     It is important that we do not misapprehend the reasons behind the Budget.  It contains a lot of goodies and assistance. When we talk about assistance, I would also hope that more

efforts be taken so that more Singaporeans will understand what is the available assistance, how they can benefit from them so that they can get out of the circle of problems that they face.  This will demand that they have knowledge and new skills so that they will remain relevant in this globalised world.  Like many Members of Parliament who conduct their meet-the-people sessions, I too have seen many Singaporeans who do not understand what programmes are available for them.      Therefore, if we do not understand what are the issues of globalisation and the effects of globalisation, we will feel

Column: 1813

squeezed. We will feel that competitiveness will not benefit us. We will feel as though the talents that could be brought into Singapore will burden us.  But they are actually to our advantage. Therefore, if we understand the concept and philosophy behind globalisation, we will not only be more prepared with the required skills, but we will also be prepared to embrace the changes that the Government will introduce, whether in terms of immigration or tax policies.  In short, we must welcome the short-term programmes to help us overcome short-term problems and, at the same time, take measures to ensure that we equip ourselves in terms of education and skills and also knowledge for future needs.  We do not want a similar situation like during the Congress on the Knowledge-based Economy organised by the Malay community where the leaders were looking ahead to the challenges of KBE, but the community was not yet ready.  We need the community to also understand the issues and challenges related to globalisation and to take full advantage of the available opportunities.

feedback were unhappy expressions against the Government.

Column: 1815

investment, it is increasingly apparent that the present direct tax regime is inadequate and hence the need to shift to an indirect form of taxation. But like the speaker before me, Mr Zainul, I feel that the Government needs to explain more about the reason and the need to shift the tax incidents to indirect taxes.

     I am very pleased to note that the focus of these offset measures is on the poor, the needy and the elderly, as it rightly should be.  The poor and lower middle income group would be the ones who would have the most difficulty adjusting to the effects of globalisation, and it is right that the most help is given to this group of people.

 

     I would also support the Government's strategy of having Workfare Income Supplement as a way to encourage those who can work to carry on working and to be as self-reliant as possible.  To me, this is a far better option and outright cash handout to residents who then have no incentive to work, and this may lead to a crutch mentality.  I am talking about mental crutch and not fiscal crutch.

 

    Sir, there are two groups of people whom I am concerned about.  The first group comprises Singaporeans who, because of globalisation or economic restructuring, are caught with negative assets and either lower income or no

Column: 1816

income.  They may be having their own purchased flats or even private properties which are now below valuation, but because they have lost their jobs or they are unable to find similar paying jobs, they are caught in a situation where they are not eligible for Government aid because of the assets they own, but yet they struggle financially because of their loss of income.

 

     Quite a few other MPs have spoken previously about the need to help this group of lower middle income Singaporeans who are caught in the middle.  I add my voice in urging the Government to find some way to provide financial relief to them. The best way to help this group is really to help them find a job that will pay a reasonable wage as before, to enable them to apply their experience and to use the skills that they have learned over the years.  But until they are able to get back on their feet, the Government should consider them to be eligible for short-term financial assistance, whenever necessary.  If nothing else, Sir, we should be sympathetic towards their situation. However, looking at the difficulties that some of them faced like not being able to get a HDB flat because they have just sold a private property, frequently at a loss, or like not being able to get a HDB loan, one cannot help but feel for their frustration.

But somehow or other, many of them feel that the better option for them is to migrate where they would be happier in another country.

 

     Even as Singapore tries to attract skilled and talented foreigners to Singapore, we should also put in our own effort to persuade our own Singaporeans that they too are talented in their own way and they too have a bright future in their own homeland.  Are our fellow Singaporeans leaving the country because of the increased cost of living? Or is it because of the pressures of living in a competitive society?  Or is it that they do not feel appreciated by the Government who feels that they are not talented enough?  Or is it because of the school system which determines their children's future from young?

 

     Next, Sir, please allow me to speak about the social security system.  I accept the basic principles which underlie the social security system which is that of self-reliance, mutual support within the family, supplemented by the Government only to the extent necessary.  But, within this system, I do not believe that we need to see Singaporeans living in abject poverty before we extend a helping hand to them.  I believe that it is not unreasonable for some lower income Singaporeans to say, "Look, I have some small savings.  But I really need them for a rainy day.  Can you give me some kind of help now because I need  some form of

Column: 1818

financial assistance?"  Or other Singaporeans may say, "Can you give me some help now, even though I have two children who can give some allowance?  But I try not to rely on them because they too have their own families to look after."  And for some older residents who say, "Yes, I have made a small profit from the sale of my HDB flat.  But I need to set them aside for my future medical bills."  And some would save for their coffin or funeral expenses.  So can you allow them to rent a subsidised flat from HDB?

 

     At the end of the day, it is really a matter of balance of deciding when to help them and how much to help them.  They are not so poor that they will be eligible for all the schemes for the needy.  But they are definitely not considered well off by any standard, that they should be considered as not needy.  The main point, Sir, is that the Government should not just turn them away because these people do not fall within the basic guidelines for financial assistance. I would urge the Government to consider allowing the CDC or the VWOs

 

 

to exercise some flexibility in assessing how to help some of the Singaporeans who are caught in the middle ground so that assistance can be more holistic in nature.

     Who decides what areas of research and development to concentrate on?  How much should the investment be?  What are the criteria for investment?  How does the Government ensure that the huge amount of monies set aside for research and development related expenditure is properly spent?  Some members of the public have already raised concerns about the area of focus for research, and I think that these concerns should properly be considered and addressed by the Government.

     Miss Penny Low (Pasir Ris-Punggol): Mr Speaker, Sir, the Budget is indeed one that reflects its theme: "Ready for the future, Ready for the world."

 

     It has sought to address the present concerns of the lower-income groups and senior citizens and takes a long-term perspective in anticipating and preparing them for the future.  The comprehensive GST package is inclusive, giving to all, including $100 to those who do not need it.  Perhaps, a website and other mechanisms could be set up to encourage people to donate this money with ease.  The Workfare bonus tried its best to cover all grounds, from the self-employed to the lower-wage workers, and served as an important and permanent wealth redistribution mechanism to narrow the increasing Gini coefficient.  A subtle but landmark change is paying the bulk of it into the future needs of this population via their health and retirement accounts via the CPF.  Although most people would prefer upfront cash, few would have the discipline to save consistently for their future needs.  It is a welcome move. 

 

     However, I was hoping that the Government would go further to address the issue of ageing population and retirement funding.  I have spoken long on

Column: 1820

this subject matter before.  Hence, I will not repeat my points.  Perhaps it is still cooking in the PMO, with Minister Lim Boon Heng leading the charge on the ageing population issue.  Nevertheless, I have filed a cut on it.

 

     Despite a good Budget, dialogue sessions on the ground revealed two groups of people feeling left out, ie, the middle-class and the homemakers.  They both felt that their contributions were not duly rewarded.  The middle-income reflected that while the safety nets are available to the lower-income group and the high-income earners can take care of themselves in the long term, they need help to build their future needs too.  The homemakers, too, reflected that their financial future is insecure, as marriages and children are no longer reliable insurance policies.  They, too, want their CPF accounts to be topped up.  It is a tall order to craft a perfect Budget, but these concerns do need to be addressed through perhaps innovative means.  Overall, I think the Budget is well received, as it delivered good news and ang pows to redistribute wealth as well as hopes for the future.

 

     My colleagues have spoken long on the redistribution of wealth.  Hence, I shall focus on the other half of the Budget, which is getting ready for the world.  In tandem with the Budget's theme, we must examine if our fiscal and non-fiscal measures are aligned with the global winds of change.  Hence, I will focus on the three power shifts that have been sweeping across the world in an unprecedented manner. 

 

First power shift - West to East (Reinventing relevance)

 

     The first power shift refers to the shift from West to East.  With the rise of three billion people from China, India, Russia and Southeast Asia, the trade route is increasingly shifting from the Atlantic to

Column: 1821

Asia.  It is clear and presents opportunities extraordinary in Asia.  However, the booming economies have also crept northwards from Southeast Asia to North Asia.  Hence, a critical question: where is Singapore in this shifting power equation?  Will Singapore still be in the nexus of the power shift or will we be sidelined?  What steps can Singapore take to ensure its place in the regional and global arena?  The Government appears to be in tune with this power shift.  Physical geography was all the rage in the Asian trade routes.  It may not be so in a borderless world.  Whether Singapore can continue to be a nexus in this changing knowledge-driven trade route will depend largely on three factors.

 

     One, is the ability to attract, groom and retain talent, its trade-link strength, and its responsiveness to fast changes.  To ready itself for a 6.5 million population, we are transforming the cityscape with ABC plan and adding plenty of entertainment places to develop Singapore into an ultra-attractive and liveable island for its residents.  Undoubtedly, major infrastructures like transport, ICT, housing and living environment would undergo visible transformation.  These are exciting measures to develop Singapore into an attractive haven for investors, professionals, workers and, of course, locals.

 

     To reposition itself as a hot-spot both regional and globally, PM Lee, SM Goh, MM Lee and, of course, Minister George Yeo have led the charge to strengthen our trade ties via FTAs and mutual investment plans.  The result - a robust relationship with China, India, Vietnam and the traditional partners like the US and Japan.  In the immediate neighbourhood, however, I think we will need to work harder.  Perhaps doing so through strengthening the ASEAN ties and platform would augur well in the long term. 

 

Column: 1822

     In this Budget, the Second Minister for Finance, Mr Tharman Shanmugaratnam, has also announced watershed measures to compete with the rising hotspots around the world.  A 2% cut in the corporate tax rate, various measures to help employers lower the tax burden and cost of engaging in new technology, a long overdue but much welcome plan to focus on the SMEs, and even a rise in the broad-based tax, ie, the GST, are all strategies to boost economic activities and ensure employment of its residents.  This Budget should also be read with the previous budgets in mind, where resources were poured into economic restructuring and deepening of our economic capabilities through the NRF.  I think our Government deserves a pat on the back for its vision and leadership.  The question, however, is how can we effectively translate this vision into reality.  How would our current R&D investments be translated into operational capabilities? 

 

     Recently, the NRF also announced a $500 million plan to invest into the IDM sector.  How will this be spent and what are the desired outcomes?  The Intelligent Nation 2015 plan intends to put Singapore at the leading edge of technology.  It is a Web 2.0 platform that plans to leverage information to lower cost, improve productivity and connectivity in a knowledge-based global economy.  In Singapore, the IDM sector grew 13% per annum, from $480 million in 1986 to $3.8 billion in value-add in 2003.  It currently employs 50,000 employees and contributes an average of $75,000 value-add per IDM worker.  In 2005, a Microsoft study revealed that, globally, from now until 2009, the total IT spending is set to rise from US$437 billion to US$562 billion.  Some three million additional IT jobs, an estimated US$190 billion in net tax revenues would be available for the governments in Europe, Latin America and the Asia Pacific.  Hence, I think the investment into

Column: 1823

the Intelligent Nation 2015 plan is a step in the right direction.

 

     To do this effectively, an extensive ecosystem, comprising the related vendors, channels, services and IT professionals that drive the industry, needs to be nurtured.  Microsoft, for example, engages some 700,000 big and small companies worldwide, including software developers and distributors, hardware producers, system integrators, and so on.  In Singapore alone, it engages just under 2,000 companies.  To achieve a multiplier effect, it uses both a top-down and bottom-up active partnership approach to build its ecosystem.  It purchases from the small players, but also empowers them with joint marketing dollars, co-funding of staff, combined development matrix and helps them build skills and enlarge their business.  The result?  Its partners generate some 90% of Microsoft's revenue. 

 

     Hence, my question is:  how can we replicate such win-win ecosystem which is extremely helpful and critical to our SMEs?  We need to ask: how well are our local SMEs leveraging on the ICT infrastructure to increase their productivity?  In fact, the SMEs hire more than 50% of the workforce but contribute less than 30% of the GDP.  MNCs, on the other hand, hire 35% of the workforce and contribute more than 50% of the GDP.  How can the Budget help SMEs to embrace technology to increase productivity and business opportunities?  Building a superb infrastructure is only half the story.  If the adoption rate is poor, it might end up as a white elephant.  I shall elaborate on this during the COS debate on the need to build an ICT ecosystem to leapfrog the growth.

 

     From the ecosystem to environment, the next big wave - climate change opportunities.  I was surprised that this year's Budget made little effort to tap on the growing opportunities in the climate

Column: 1824

change.  I was in Davos for the World Economic Forum in January.  Delegates arrived raving about their climate change initiatives.  As part of the Forum of Young Global Leaders' Climate Change Task Force, we launched a Love Earth Movement, with Shimon Peres, Vinod Khosla and Claudia Schiffer as our spokespersons.  We had anticipated 200 guests, but the turn out doubled.  I am not sure if it was the Love Movement or Claudia Schiffer who attracted the overwhelming response, but it was clear that the climate change issue is no longer a mere Green Peace agenda.  In fact, it has turned from Green to Gold, with green collar jobs, green funds and green dollars featuring big on the business agenda.  If we have signed the Kyoto Protocols, issued green building guidelines and, now, intend to build capabilities in alternative fuel, should we not ride the big Green to Gold Opportunity Wave to bring more jobs and dollars home?  

 

     However, the climate change opportunities can only be successful if tackled holistically, with changes in consumer behaviour too.  Hence, I would like to see efforts, whether through legislation, moral suasion or incentives, to be given to green behaviour.  A few years ago, BP's CEO, Lord John Browne, initiated a 'looking for CO2' effort to reduce greenhouse gases.  The initial process costs $20 million but saved BP a handsome $650 million.  By 2006, the savings reached $1.5 billion, all in US dollars.  Lord Browne said they "set out to do good ...   and ended up doing well."  What about us?  I think a good start would be the public sector, which is the biggest consumer of energy.  Tweaking our transport transformation plan to include bicycle and wheelchair lanes in new towns and on new roads is another completely thinkable, albeit out-of-the-box option.  In short, can we be more responsive and be on top of the ICT and Green to Gold Wave? 

 

Column: 1825

Second shift - Shift of economic clout from producers to consumers, ie, from mass production to customer-centric mindset


     The Industrial Age Ford-black car one-size-fits-all mass production method suffers an ever decreasing profit margin.  With high cost and high standard of living, we need to fetch a premium on our factors of production.  To illustrate, Nokia wins by producing phones with highly customisable exterior cover, with a wide array of options to personalise the software content, such as the ringtones and wallpaper, so that each user can have a unique product in hand.  In the February 2007 Time Magazine, Bill Gates was asked about the NEAR future technology, he replied that "TV will be sent over the Internet, and then you do not have to think about channels.  If there is a news segment, and you'd like soccer, we'll show you more about soccer.  If there's another city which where you want to know the weather, that will be in your news report .....  the computer will have a camera where it can recognise who's there.  A mirror won't just be a mirror, it will be a digital mirror where you can try out different outfits and get advice.  Maybe it will say, 'Hey, you don't look good in it.'"  I would add that a standard package of creative and innovative products may not be sufficient.  It has to be customisable to suit the unique individuals, in order to be the ultimate winner. 

 

     Is Singapore ready for this brave new world?  Are our Government, businesses and people ready for this paradigm shift?  Since our most precious factor of production is human, and our service industry is a rising contributor to the GDP, developing a service culture is critical.  MOM launched Go the Extra Miles (GEMS), a nation-wide campaign to promote good service.  Four Million Smiles

Column: 1826

was rolled out to welcome the World Bank-IMF delegates last year.  Yet, last November, it was reported that Singapore's ranking in world service standards dropped from 17 to 26.  In contrast, Hong Kong jumped from 10 to 4. So, does the nation really understand that good customised services go beyond mere smiles?  A campaign can create the needed smiles, but sincere, personalised and creative solutions to fulfil customer needs must come from the hearts and heads.  Where should we start?  Since the public sector is a major employer and has a leading effect on the rest of Singapore, I will focus on the need to cultivate a world-class civil service for a top-tier First World economy.


     To be sure, we have an efficient administration that is the envy of other countries.  Yet, while efficiency is its strength, creativity is not.  Ministers and parliamentarians tend to be mission-driven, but they, too, are limited by their bureaucrats' interpretation of their intention into policies and procedures.  The civil service translates them into simplified boxes and game-rules that are fair to all, have no room for corruption, and often easy for everyone to understand because it adopts the common denominator.  Over the years, we have streamlined processes to the point of flowchart yes-no clarity.  Hence, anything that falls within the box or norms can be treated expeditiously.  This has worked so far, in a world where mass production and standard answer are the norms.  But what happens when the query is innovative and original?  I think it gets lost in the lallangs sometimes.


     Feedback from the private and people sectors points to growing frustrations with the rigidities and follow-the-rules mentality amongst the civil service.  A social commentator, in the form of Jack Neo, the movie maker, devoted an entire movie to this end.  His film, "Just Follow Law",  maybe an exaggerated caricature of the black-and-white paper-filling, "please

Column: 1827

submit written proposal first", "sorry not my department" bureau-craziness,

 

 

but it is a reflection of the frustrations felt on the ground.

 

    To be fair, efforts like ZIP, Cut Waste Panel and the Pro-enterprise Panel have helped. However, the marketplace changes far outpace the slower mindset change in our civil service.  We need to move much, much faster, or risk losing our talents and businesses. Surely, there are good examples too. One is found in the case of MDA and a film production company called MegaMedia. Their partnership has gone on to grow MegaMedia as one of the largest HD producers in Singapore and also a major distributor of HDTV in the region.

 

     Surely, the civil servants are neither good nor bad.  In their personal life, they are just as creative as you and me.  But once they arrive at their office, they "just follow law".  If we quantify this loss in dollars value, it might add up to a mega sum on lost opportunities.  I suspect that they may not be as cold-blooded as it seems. They are possibly frustrated that although they too want to innovate, there are restrictions in place.  So better 'play safe' and be kiasu.  Perhaps, it is the minority, but such behaviour is linked to yeast and it needs only a small amount to affect the whole dough. 

 

   So what can be done?  I suggest that the Budget allocates some resources to the civil service to upgrade their innovation and emotional quotient, maybe we call that IEQ. I would like to suggest the right to make mistakes. This practice by large French corporations assumes that only persons who do not make mistakes are the ones that did nothing new.  Instead of getting a blemish in their record for failed attempts, they get rewarded for taking risk and get a blemish for not innovating.  Perhaps, we should adapt their system to incentivise adoption of innovations by civil servants.  Only then

Column: 1828

can Singapore support an innovative culture.

 

    Another suggestion is active secondment of the civil servants to the private and people sectors or even international agencies.  This will not only provide our civil servants with an experiential understanding of customers' needs, but also enrich their perspectives on redefining customer-centric services.  Examples of countries running similar initiatives include Luxembourg and UK.  In fact, the UK government has an initiative known as Interchange which even permits private sector individuals to be seconded to the civil service.  Vacancies and corresponding job responsibilities in various Ministries and the private sector are posted on the web portal. Such mutual postings reduce administrative cost and improve mutual understanding and effectiveness.

 

    Another seemingly unrelated but critical measure is in improving our PMETs' capabilities, many of whom are also in our civil service. The Budget recognised the need for lifelong learning, but it did not go far enough to address the urgency.  As our economy moves up the value chain, the PMETs form the backbone of our economy and play a leadership role in guiding our workforce.  In the long run, our competitiveness, especially in the local enterprises and SMEs, will have to depend on our PMETs' capabilities.  PMETs are our next generation business leaders who will assume top positions in MNCs and SMEs in the next five to 15 years.  If our PMET layer is weak, this will blunt our competitive edge.  If we become overly dependent on overseas PMETs, we will suffer.  Being a revolving door for second-class PMETs will hardly help us to become a top-tier first-world economy. We need to allocate more resources to upgrade our PMETs, lest it becomes our weakest link.

 

    To sum up, having an effective civil service and a proficient PMET layer to

Column: 1829

lead the charge in shaping our economy and service culture would augur well in the new power equation where customer needs are paramount. 

 

Third shift:  Institutional power to individual power

 

    The third shift, from institutional power to individual power.  Tom Friedman said the world is flat. The third shift sees power moving from the traditional and institutional centres to the periphery.  Power has become widespread, as vertical command and control structures give way to horizontal networks of social communities and collaborative platforms. This is especially prevalent in the e-arena, as evident in the ohmynews.com where every citizen is a reporter, and more recently, more than half a million netizens got behind a Chinese blogger - Mr Rui Chengang, to rid Starbucks from the Forbidden City.   During the NKF saga, I think there were some 15,000 signatures done on the on-line petition as well. The new found freedom in the e-arena has translated into e-voices that critic government and change social values and norms, especially amongst our younger netizens.  It has also created countless little brothers vis-a-vis the big brother, as seen in ST's Stomp, YouTube and a surveillance society. 

 

    So what can the Government do and how can the Budget help? Obviously, Government needs to redefine its role and form a new social compact with its people.  It must recognise that it needs to partner the private and people sectors more wholeheartedly, and encourage the growth of responsible civic organisations, as well as inculcate national pride.  This means investing into our people and spending more on cementing our social compact.  The Budget announcement to develop Singapore into a Philanthropy Hub is a good start. Removing the three 20:80 rules will certainly spur the growth of a

Column: 1830

multi-billion dollar philanthropy industry as well as civic organisations.   They are two sides of the coin. The global trend in philanthropy is the strong emergence of strategic philanthropy.  Made famous by the US$71 billion worth of Melinda and Gates Foundation, the more than $100 billion strong global funds, these philanthropic dollars look for strategy investment in transformative and sustainable for-profit as well as not-for-profit enterprise.  The idea is to ensure that each dollar can achieve a multiplier effect on meeting social gaps.

 

    The sister of this strategic philanthropy is social entrepreneurship. Social entrepreneurs (SEs) are individuals who address social needs with a business model because they believe that the market is the most powerful and sustainable place to match needs with viable products and services.  They are innovators who transform social needs into market niche.  In other words, they help solve the Government's challenges at a discounted rate or even for free!  Hence, my call here is to ask for more space, resources and investments into social entrepreneurship.  It is also to ask for more facilitation of philanthropic dollars to jumpstart local social entrepreneurs. 

 

    Please let me declare my interest as the Founder of the Social Innovative Park or SIP, a non-profit organisation that seeks to educate, empower and enhance social entrepreneurship.  To relate my experience, since our inauguration about a year ago, we witnessed tremendous interest from the people and private sectors to join us.  At SIP, we have successfully brought in five major corporate partners who have expressed keen interest in giving us some 3,000 employee-volunteers as well as a group of social entrepreneur incubatees. We have also motivated and created a social entrepreneur TV series which is currently screened on CNA every Friday night, called the "Changemakers".  These results

Column: 1831

would not be possible without the encouragement of MCYS, but more is needed to boost the sector.  In particular, the mere $3 million social enterprise fund appears more like a market teaser than a serious effort at boosting social entrepreneurship.  We need more serious dollars if we want to build a self-reliant society and enforce the many-helping-hands approach.  These dollars must have its priority in empowering local social enterprises.   The civil service must also ensure its role as the facilitator and not the person doing social entrepreneurship.  It must facilitate and empower local bottom-up initiatives and create a conducive environment for its growth. 

 

     More tax incentives and dollars should also go into kick-starting an integrated approach to corporate philanthropy. In the US alone, corporate philanthropic foundations pour some US$30 billion into their endeavours every year.  In the words of Mr Rochelle Lazarus, Chairman and CEO of Ogilvy & Mather Worldwide, "the debate about whether corporate philanthropy is right for the bottom line is long over. The market has spoken and said it cares whether companies are good citizens; ...  Engaging your company in corporate philanthropy is now part of being a good CEO".  Ogilvy is also a corporate partner of SIP.  Another of our partner, salesforce.com, incorporated this philosophy right from its inception. The result?  A legendary rise to become a billion dollar company in eight years!  It has attributed part of its success to its 1+1+1, and now a recent plus one, model -  equity, profits, employee time and the green movement.  In fact, most of its social projects and bottom-up, ie, initiated by its employees or requested by social groups.  85% of their global workforce is active in philanthropy.  They currently support more than 1,000 NGOs worldwide. 

 

     One social entrepreneur that salesforce support is John Wood.  John

Column: 1832

resigned from Microsoft to bring education to children in developing countries to break their poverty cycle through his SE called "Room to Read".  With strong support from corporate partners, local agencies and entrepreneurial knowledge, John's six-year-old venture is now found in 1,000 villages in six Asian countries, with 2,000 libraries and one million books in store for about a million children, and offers 1,000 scholarships.  He wants to be the Microsoft of the charity world, a trusted global brand. A key element of his success was found in his customised solution models.  He relies on native program officers who are personally invested in their national education and familiar with local rules and culture to tailor its development approach to meet local needs.  Perhaps, our civil service can also study this customised solution approach to better help our local SEs.

 

    On national pride, I think we should foster that with great urgency.  On 23rd February this year, the Straits Times reported on how the lack of local support diminishes the chance of a Singaporean chef shining on the world culinary stage.  Another guy, Jack Sim, founder of the World Toilet Organisation (WTO), laments that he loves his country but his country does not love him. Apparently, he was initially rejected by MEWR for Singapore to host the World Sanitation Fund Forum. This forum will see a thousand delegates comprising UN agencies, funders and global experts.  He said that he was told that if it was successful elsewhere for the first year, they might consider to host it in Singapore in the second year. Fortunately, when Prof. Tommy Koh heard that it was moving to Thailand, he garnered enough support for it to be held here.  Jack said that, "Everywhere, WTO is accepted and supported except in Singapore. The answer I got was: prophets are usually not welcome at home."  Jack's family has applied for Australian PR.  How can we

Column: 1833

keep talents like him? Why are we not proud of our own local talent and how can we inculcate national pride so that we can turn the four million smiles into four million ambassadors?

 

    To send a strong signal of trust and support, I suggest that we rationalise this spirit in respect to Lifelong Learning Fund, to move from a training institute-centric fund to an individual account, allowing our fellow Singaporeans to bear responsibilities in determining their career pursuit. This will send a strong signal to our people to be responsible for their own livelihood with a little help from the Government.  In US, to encourage the SMEs, projects under ---

    To conclude, the present Singapore is built on a strong foundation by a resolute and hardworking population, under astute Government guidance.  In the rising power of the three shifts, the essence to survive is to recognise and harness opportunities by responding appropriately.      Mr Wee Siew Kim (Ang Mo Kio): Mr Speaker, Sir, thank you for allowing me to join in the debate.

 

     Since the Budget announcement, I have heard positive feedback from many of my residents as well as from the businesses.  Many perceive it as a generous Budget that has taken into consideration the needs of the various segments of the population.

     Second, the Budget has laid plans for a vibrant city that is plugged into the world.  Singaporeans and people from all around the world alike will want to live, work and play here.  Singapore aims to provide a First World living environment that many have and will be proud to call home and country.
