Column: 1835

shows that we are taking great steps in achieving our goal as a more gracious society.  It caters to the needs of the elderly, the lower-income, the sick and the young.  The message is clear - as long as one does his or her fair share, no one will be left behind.

 

Singapore a forward-looking country

 

     Let me elaborate on the first point - Singapore looks ahead with confidence.  Riding on the crest of three consecutive years of economic and employment growth, this confidence can be easily brushed aside as a good feeling which a rising tide brings in.  The skeptics will have us believe that at the next economic downturn, this confidence would evaporate and all the issues and worries that confound a small nation state would bubble up to the surface again. 

 

     I sincerely believe otherwise.  Yes, growth is important and we will continue to strive for growth to ensure that the next generation -  our children  -  would enjoy a high standard of living just as we are now enjoying a standard that is way above what our parents had experienced.  While confidence can be partially attributed to good economic performance, I also believe Singapore’s confidence comes from our people who have proven that we have got what it takes to pull together and confront adversity.  

 

     Over the last few years, we have weathered multiple crises as a nation and come out stronger.  We have undergone two economic downturns within a six-year span and we took the necessary bitter medicine in order to recover.  SARS struck us from the blind side and we pulled together.  When we woke up one morning to terrorism threatening to tear through the threads of our multi-racial society, we faced it as a rational people of all colours and faiths determined to preserve the harmony that we have enjoyed as a nation.  

 

Column: 1836

     As a small nation, we also have had brickbats thrown at us from our neighbours but we continue to stretch out to offer aid and continue to be in pole position to push for regional solidarity because it is for the good of the region.   All these had built our resilience as a society; confident in our role and place in the sun.  And in this Budget, we continue to build on our strengths, continue to forge new horizons, and continue to plan for the future of our nation.

 

     One tangible evidence of our relentless focus on building the future is the commitment to ensure that every child has a first-rate education.  And we have seen the results from the significant rise in general educational levels over the years.  The unwavering focus on education had certainly borne fruits.  Singaporean managers, executives, and workers are highly sought after.  The hallmarks of discipline, dependability, diligence and rigour of our work force set us apart and ahead.  But the pressure is relentless and we cannot afford to rest on our laurels lest we fall behind.  We must continue to provide additional avenues for Singaporeans to advance and train themselves. 

 

     With the advent of the Post Secondary Education Account, the onus of keeping up, of taking the initiative to keep oneself ahead are firmly in the hands of the individual.  Each student can choose how he or she uses the money.  The Government has truly put life-long learning within the reach of all students.  In addition, the increased Polytechnic subsidies for older students are extremely welcomed as workers can expect to be trained and retrained several times in the course of their work life. 

 

     However, I seek the Minister's consideration on two points that had often been raised in my interactions with my

Column: 1837

residents. The first is the desire of our young to take a second diploma or degree.  They have met with rejections from our educational institutions.  I hear that the rejection is underpinned by the belief that in allowing them to take a second diploma/degree in alternate fields, it would deprive other students of an opportunity, especially if the courses are subsidised.  Clearly, the desire to stem out waste of scarce resources from students' extended stay in educational institutions is understandable.  However, with our new mindset of providing life-long learning opportunities, I seek a relaxation of this constraint.  Allow eligible students who may have made a wrong choice or have found a new interest or who are capable to pursue second diplomas/degrees the ability to do so.   

 

     Secondly, give a second chance to those students who had not fared well or had wasted their opportunities by failing to be diligent or had come under the influence of bad company but realised their mistakes later.  Our education system must be more tolerant of failures and our students given additional chances to try again.  This is the entrepreneurial spirit that we are trying to foster, so let us start with our young.  Let us re-examine the rules that hinder second opportunities in the pursuit of learning and eradicate them.

 

Singapore as a vibrant city


     The second signal from the Budget was about Singapore embracing globalisation and providing first-world living for all.  Today, Singaporeans are internationally mobile and many are working in all corners of the world.  Increasingly, we must develop the hardware, the software and the heartware to connect our people from all over the world to Mothership Singapore.  Earlier I spoke about national confidence that comes from a collective determination and

Column: 1838

consciousness borne out of surviving adverse challenges.  This is part of the Singapore software and heartware. 

 

     This Budget also laid out the promise of the hardware. To Singaporeans and to the foreigners who set up home here, a vision is painted - a future vibrant city in green and blue.  In true Singapore style, we are not selling empty promises.  It is built on concrete plans.  The early phases of this vision have already materialised in drawings and pictures and are being rolled out.

 

     The future city of Singapore - painted vividly in words, and more excitingly in pictures and models - is certainly where all of us want to stay and grow old in.  The environment is a key part of the pride we have in Singapore.  Wherever I go and travel, whenever I hear of Singapore being referred to as a garden city, it brings out the pride in me, and I am sure it brings out the pride in all of us. Hence, PM's vision of a Singapore - green and blue - would excite Singaporeans young and old, and will excite new Singaporeans as well.

 

     It is encouraging to hear that close attention would be paid to the heartlands where Singaporeans spend much of their leisure time.  Large swathes of older estates would be rejuvenated.  This is eagerly awaited.  At Jalan Kayu, my residents are looking forward to building an extension to our void deck community centre with a stand alone multi-purpose hall and street soccer facilities.  We hope to incorporate the green and blue environment too by having a garden on the roof of the multi-purpose hall and skyways to directly link the third or fourth floors of nearby blocks of flats to the roof garden.  It would certainly soften the harsh and jarring outlines of the CC extension and create an environment that all my residents would be proud of.  To make this a reality, I hope for inter-agency cooperation among the People's Asso

Column: 1839

ciation, HDB, NParks, MEWR - a lot of people working together.  With the hopes of our people raised by this vision, I hope that the Ministers in charge of the different agencies would allow a collective approach to this project.  It is a small start but it could well be an exemplary showcase. 

 

     Staying for the moment still in the heartlands, I would like to speak about another heartware programme - the Lift Upgrading Programme (LUP).  The LUP is often an eagerly awaited improvement for the older blocks of flats.  Understandably, there is a limit to expenses and this is by stipulating a cost cap per benefiting household unit.  While the residents benefit from lifts on every level, they also hope to enjoy additional enhancements in the process, eg, decorative tiles, security cameras, planters, better lighting, etc.  Grassroots leaders tasked with helping to reach many of these decisions on what to have strive to create an environment that the residents can also be proud of.  We are proud that our HDB flats are attractive and very different from the drab and often under-maintained public housing of many other countries.

 

     To be able to provide residents with enhanced value add from the LUP, I would like to suggest a modification of the cost cap per benefiting unit calculation.  This cap can be used initially for the identification of the blocks that are eligible for the LUP.  However, once this hurdle is crossed, let the cost be looked at from an accumulated precinct basis.  This way, all the blocks in a precinct could be treated in a collective manner to achieve an overall look and common enhancing features post-LUP.  As the blocks in a single precinct are often of different designs - point blocks, segmented blocks, common corridor blocks -  by moving away from a cost cap on a single block basis once the eligibility is determined, I believe, would be able to better meet the overall needs of the

Column: 1840

residents and enhance the precinct living environment.

 

Singapore as a more gracious society

    

     The last signal that I detected in this Budget is that great strides are being taken to inculcate the characteristics of a gracious and compassionate society that we strive to be.   Hence, it is encouraging that informal workers not only merited a mention in the Minister’s speech but they are also  recognised and treated no differently from self-employed persons.  These informal workers do odd jobs on an ad hoc and often erratic basis.  For many of them, if there is no work, there is no food.   These are the people who are generally lower skilled and with a lower education.  For many of them, the new economy no longer requires their skills that they had been trained in.  But many still retain good work ethics and prefer to be independent than to receive hand-outs.  This is not to downplay the Workfare programme and its merits.  It is about creating the additional opportunities for these people to earn a livelihood.  Hence, I repeat my previous calls, which I have been making for several years now, to make it easier for these people to become small stallholders or hawkers.  The present approach of tendering out all stalls in the market and hawker centres makes it almost impossible for some of them with limited means to attempt to start making a living this way.  Maybe a cooperative to facilitate the entry of small, poor stallholders and hawkers could be looked into.

 

     The Senior Citizens' Bonus recognises that retirees and aged citizens dip into savings for their daily expenditure.  The additional $1,000 is definitely very welcome.  Every year, we celebrate Senior Citizens' Week to recognise the contributions of our aged residents.  At the same time, we reinforce the younger citizens' appreciation for the generation that had toiled and built the Singapore that we enjoy today. 

 

Column: 1841

     However, amongst these senior residents are some who are not well educated and not accustomed to planning ahead.  As a result, they land themselves in a predicament of being a non citizen in the land they had lived, worked and grew old in. Many had worked here, contributed economically, but somehow never got around to being a PR or a citizen.  Some have children who are citizens and have served National Service.  In their golden years, they yearn to be Singapore citizens, not only because most see this as their only home where their roots are but in reality they also have nowhere else to go.  Many feel that their PR or citizenship applications had not made progress because of the concern that older people put undue stress and burden on Singapore's social and health services.  I have seen the appeals of many of these residents.

 

 

So I am asking that the hard-nosed argument that they are no longer economically contributing be reconsidered.  While I understand that the working population of today and tomorrow would have to shoulder a heavier burden, I believe that this is a burden willingly shouldered.  I hope that the Government would consider giving due consideration to the applications of such older residents when they seek to be PRs or citizens. This is a gesture of compassion, one of gratitude that these people too had played a role in Singapore's formative years, and recognise that they too deserve to be given the benefits of having given most of their productive lives to this country.

 

Population - adoption


     From my call of allowing some older people to be PRs and citizens, I want to turn to the other end of the age spectrum - adoption of children. People adopt children for various reasons. Some adopt because they love children but are unable to conceive; some adopt because they

Column: 1842

want to enjoy the joys of parenthood or feel that life is not complete without being a parent but they were unable to have their own.  Others adopt because they genuinely believe in wanting to do good, to provide care and love to the less unfortunate who are unable to fend for themselves. The adopted and their natural children live side by side.

 

     So, as a more gracious society, could we not encourage, facilitate and simplify the rules and procedures for adoption of children?  Suggestions to aid this process include the provision of financial incentives and to simplify the entire adoption process. 

 

Government to provide financial incentives or relief for child adoption

 

     The Government now provides certain tax rebates to parents with a third child. Just, recently, the period of maternity leave to mothers was increased. All these have been done to encourage and assist with parenthood.  Similarly, the Government can consider providing a one-off financial subsidy to eligible individuals or couples looking to adopt a child.  This subsidy could be used for any purpose that goes  towards making the adoption easier and more affordable, for example, paying for adoption proceedings, purchasing clothing, education, not unlike a baby bonus.

 

Reduce paperwork and costs

 

     The entire adoption process for a child born in Singapore could also take as long as 10 months. When I look at 10 months,  I thought somebody made a benchmark which actually produced their own child.  But to adopt a child born out of Singapore is subject to even more compliance requirements and the entire process will certainly take much longer.  And I do understand issues do emanate from the countries as well.  Where it is within the control and ability of the Government to

Column: 1843

simplify and reduce the adoption process time, we should do so.  For example, shorten the time to complete the Home Study Report (HSR). This HSR essentially states if the potential adoptive parent is suitable to adopt a child and provide a caring home environment. This HSR typically takes about six weeks to complete.

 

     The current adoption procedure also requires one who plans to adopt a child born outside of Singapore to obtain a dependant pass before the child may stay in Singapore with the adoptive parents until the court proceedings are completed and the Adoption Order granted. The court proceedings, together with the related paperwork, can sometimes take five to six months and the process is costly and time-consuming. The MCYS could look into the need for the dependant pass and security bond requirements, as well as the necessity for a court order. Legalities should not stand in the way of, or delay the opportunity of allowing, the child and parents to start bonding and creating a home environment as soon as possible.  Is the HSR not itself the basis for all these to happen? 


     Singapore has also signed a Note of Agreement on the adoption of children from the PRC. Entering into such bilateral agreements will certainly help smoothen the adoption processes between countries. Singapore could also look into similar agreements with other Asian neighbours, such as Malaysia and Indonesia. 


     With the need to grow our population, and as we welcome new immigrants, I believe that we should similarly ease the adoption process as the adopted children raised and nurtured in Singapore homes ought to be just as worthy citizens.

GST increase.  Considering this is the second time I have fallen ill in three Budget debates, maybe it is the latter reason.

Column: 1847

the distance, especially for those who need it the most: lower income Singaporeans.  In the words of our Senior Minister, the benefits must outweigh the increase in prices.

 

      As the GST increase will be a permanent one, I would like to ask the Second Minister for Finance what happens to the additional subsidies for healthcare, education and conservancy charges in five years’ time.  Will they be discontinued?  It seems that the offset package to deal with the GST increase is not too dissimilar with past packages such as the Economic Restructuring Shares or Progress Package.

 

      However, I think there is a much clearer recognition this time that although we may benefit from globalisation, there always will be a group of Singaporeans who need help from their country to keep up.  It is, first and foremost, the responsibility of this Government to ensure there is a safety net for this group.  I do not see this as planting the seeds for an entitlement mentality to take root, but rather as a note of encouragement to those who are willing to help themselves.

 

    With that in mind, the WIS scheme is the most positive feature of this year’s Budget.  Singapore now has a means to rebalance the playing field for lower income Singaporeans living in a changed world.  The implementation of Workfare as the fourth pillar in Singapore’s social safety net is a recognition of market realities - that globalisation will exacerbate the income disparity between the rich and the poor.  Given how unabashedly capitalistic the Singapore system is, I hope that Workfare is a sign that we not let the market be a substitute for democracy and democratic principles, one of which is to ensure that no one gets left behind.  The politics of class and social inequality caused by an accelerating income divide could not be more

Column: 1848

detrimental to our national interests.  There will always be income disparity, but it is how we manage it, so it does not become an income divide that is entrenched and cannot be bridged, that counts.  Workfare is a crucial step to demonstrate and nurture the sense of social integration that the nation of Singapore needs.

 

      Looking to the future, and some possible scenarios, for example, if Singapore’s Gini coefficient continues to increase, and the income gap continues to widen, can the Second Minister for Finance say if the WIS amounts or the qualifying income criteria, as the case may be, would be suitably increased?  Likewise, as our population increases from 4.5 million and, therefore, when our GST revenue rises above $1.5 billion a year, or the GST rate is increased again, would the Workfare amounts or the criteria be adjusted accordingly?

 

      While some Members in this House might in time like to see less people on Workfare, I think it is logical that self-sufficiency, especially in a globalised economy with a regressive consumption tax, follows a bell curve. We should always extend the

 

 

helping hand of Workfare to the bottom 20% of income earners to remain true to the objectives of the scheme and to the interests of lower income Singaporeans and the nation as a whole.  We cannot call ourselves an inclusive society, otherwise.

 

    However, the WIS scheme is not a silver bullet that can alleviate all the pressing social needs of the lower income, especially in their retirement. How likely is it that the bottom 20% to 30% of income earners would reach a self-sufficient level to last throughout their retirement, even on the wings of Workfare?  If any sense of complacency creeps in, I worry more that it will strike our policy planners than our Workfare recipients.  Even with Workfare,

Column: 1849

I think we should look to have a multi-tier pension and healthcare system with an important role for social risk pooling.

 

     While this may take some time, one thing that can really help the lower income groups is to improve the interest rates of their CPF funds. The current baseline of 2.5% for the Ordinary Account is too low, especially if GST is going up this year and in the future.  Should we not rethink how we peg CPF interest rates?  Even Malaysia's Employee Provident Fund pays a higher interest of 5.5%.  With the way Workfare here is calibrated, it is quite clear that the Government's priority is to build up the CPF accounts of the lower income.  If this is so important, then should not higher interest rates be set for CPF funds, including Medisave and Special Accounts?

 

     On a final note on Workfare, what of those "aunties" and "uncles" who scour the streets and our estates to collect drink cans, old newspapers and cardboard boxes to sell for recycling just to earn a few dollars to put food in their tummies for the day? It hardly seems that the WIS scheme is within their reach, even to contribute to Medisave.  Yet, they are making an effort to find a means of income, however paltry, no different than how workers who qualify for Workfare strive to stay employed.  The former, in fact, need more help.  What can be done for them?  If the Government is willing to help 438,000 Singaporeans through Workfare, it should be more generous to the fraction of Singaporeans who need help from the Public Assistance Scheme.  The monthly aid should definitely be increased in view of the GST hike.

 

     Sir, I am under no illusion that the Government can provide all the solutions to our social issues and concerns.  In the economic aspect, Singapore has done well compared to the rest of the region.  But if

Column: 1850

we want to climb to the top half of the First World league table, it is time to measure our successes differently. It is time to give equal weight to our nation's social progress, and be seen to do so.  We need to be as ambitious about forging our very own Singapore national culture and strengthening the relationships among all Singaporeans as we are about growing our GDP and signing Free Trade Agreements, and be seen to do so.  In this, Singaporeans have as much a role to play as the Government.  Concepts, such as national identity, social cohesion, empathising with the less fortunate - these are goals we should aim for with renewed vigour.  As a Malay Singaporean friend of mine aptly put it, we need to add more perasaan and semangat into our nation.  In order for us to be a more inclusive society, we need more feeling and spirit. 

 

     First, let me address the issue of perasaan or feeling.  There are two things we can do.  Firstly, we can find ways to celebrate volunteerism so that Singapore becomes a conducive place for volunteering to be a way of life.  Otherwise, how can the "many helping hands" approach be a successful and sustainable sacred cow?  Without volunteers, it would be more of a red herring.  So we should aim for a higher volunteer participation rate this year.  The MCYS' key performance indicator for the estimated volunteer participation in 2007 is 15.5%. There is no change from last year, and only a slight increase from 2005.  Of course, we should strive for quality and quantity, and Singaporeans should volunteer because they feel they want to and not because they think they need to.

 

     Secondly, we can find various ways to pay tribute to our elderly.  Singapore's success is founded on the hard work of our parents and our grandparents.  Our First World aspirations and achievements are built on their sacrifices.  We stand on

Column: 1851

their shoulders.  We should look to the elderly as gems in our society, as a valuable and priceless resource of our country, not just as workers but as citizens. We would need a rather qualitative KPI here.  We would need to listen to the feedback from the elderly Singaporeans through the media and other official channels like REACH to gauge how we are faring in our policies and our personal interaction with them.

 

     Now, let me talk about semangat or spirit.  Mr Speaker, Sir, the creation of Post-Secondary Education Accounts for young Singaporeans and the support for lifelong learning to all Singaporeans are examples of how to infuse some semangat in this year's Budget.  In order for Singapore to fully imbibe in the "can do, will do, do well" attitude, however, I think it is important we allow room for failure.  Speaking of globalisation, just think of the dot.com bust a few years ago, and then look at the world around us today. 

 

      In Singapore, the tried and tested is so often the path of choice.  I can see examples of how we are trying to foster alternative paths, such as in education, but are we ready to shake off the shackles of fear of failure in all aspects?  Sometimes, it seems we have convinced ourselves that we are too small to risk failure, and this is seeped through various levels and ways of thinking.  But the notion that we cannot afford to fail or take risks is a hurdle in the journey to bigger and better things.  Failure is one of the best teachers.  ERC Holdings, for example, one of the Economic Development Board's many partners, helps budding entrepreneurs with their start-ups.  One of their mission objectives is to help struggling enterprises.  They are turnaround specialists.  This is a great initiative, and I think we should give failure more publicity - from those who have it around to those who are still trying. If next year's Budget could include

Column: 1852

these stories, and not just the straightforward runaway success stories, then it would have even more semangat.

 

     Finally, Sir, I would like to say this Budget places the focus back again on the value of the Singapore citizenship.  The creation of the PSEA, support for lifelong learning, wages and savings supplements - these are good ways to enhance the value of the Singapore citizenship.  I believe it is important to focus on the value, rather than the cost of the Singapore citizenship which unfortunately I thought was the case last year when the cut and subsidies for permanent residents and foreigners in education and healthcare were announced.  It is not good for the semangat of this country when we start focusing on costs to evaluate if we are getting a fair deal as Singapore citizens.  We should focus on how much of an enabler the Singapore citizenship is.  Does it enable us to gain an advantage in education?  Does it give us a cushion against the unrelentless market?  Does it enable us to exercise our vote?  Does it give us semangat?

 

     Sir, I support the Budget.

 

 

2.07 pm

 

     Mr Chiam See Tong (Potong Pasir): Thank you, Sir, for allowing me this opportunity to join in the debate.

 

      Hong Kong's corporate tax rate is 17.5%, 0.5% lower than Singapore's.  There is talk that Hong Kong may lower its corporate tax rate to 16.5%.  The Hong Kong Legislative Assembly shall be meeting today to decide whether its corporate tax rate shall be lowered further.  Hong Kong has a lower corporate tax rate than Singapore.  Yet, it has no GST.  Does Singapore need to raise its GST by a further 2 percentage points?  Not necessary, says a writer in his letter to the Forum page, if land sale is seen as revenue.

 

Column: 1853

     Government never sells to the public land in fee simple, that is, freehold.  It only sells leases with 30 years, 99 years or whatever length the tenure it decides.  After the expiry of the leases, those lands revert to the Government.  In any event, IRAS treats the earnings of multiple sales of land within a year not as capital appreciation, but as income and are subject to tax. The returns on land sales can be treated as revenue by the Government.  If the Government is not obsessed with having a budget surplus on every Budget day, but only aims for a balanced budget, there is no need for a GST hike.  It only has to use cash generated by land sales to balance the budget.  The two percentage point increase in GST will raise an additional $1.5 billion in revenue.  This, according to the Minister, is needed to cover for the loss of revenue in implementing Workfare and the lowering of the 2% corporate tax.  The proceeds from the sale of land are in excess of $4 billion. This sum of $4 billion is more than the sums spent on Workfare and the loss of taxes when the corporate tax is lowered.  They can easily be used to pay for the loss of revenue.

 

     The 2% increase in GST would hit the poor harder than the rich.  The rich would not feel the effects of the raise in GST.  But the poor certainly will.  Generally, the hike in GST is regressive in that the percentage of income spent on goods liable for taxation is higher among the low income groups.  Regressiveness is often increased by a practice of applying the same tax to cheaper brands as to the more expensive ones.  The GST, unlike other taxes, cannot be used flexibly as a weapon for fighting inflation and maintaining economic stability.  It would appear that as long as the economy is good, there is every likelihood that the GST rate will increase. Increases shall be a feature of the Budget until the 10% mark is reached.  The last time the

Column: 1854

Government distributed giveaways through the Progress Package, many people were unhappy because their incomes were wrongly determined and they received less of the payouts.  Those poor people happened to be living in private housing but were classified with the rich.  This time round, I hope the Government would finetune their efforts to determine the recipient's income more accurately.

 

     I have called upon for the abolishing of the estate duty in this House before.  I now support the call made by Mr Inderjit Singh to scrap estate duty.  Estate duty collected by the Government each year is not significant.  Singapore shall be better off if estate duty is taken off the statutes book.

 

     Globalisation has forced the Workfare Income Supplement scheme upon the PAP.  I support the concept of this scheme.  Its principles are sound.  The income gap between the better paid workers and the lower paid workers must be narrowed.  Singapore is a First World country and its workers should not be paid the Third World wages.  The WIS scheme is a good thing.  But at this present moment, I cannot accept its mode of implementation, that is, one-off payment and not permanent.  The WIS scheme should be implemented in the spirit for which it is intended, give meaningful help to the low wage workers.  The WIS should be paid, for a start, twice a year, and to be made permanent.  I do not think that the WIS scheme will create a crutch mentality because the workers must be working first before he can receive a wage supplement. There is no free meal for him.  The worker must be working first before he can receive help.

 

     Now, I would like to mention two groups of people.  The first group is the housewives and the second group is the contract workers, especially the contract workers working in the airport.  The

Column: 1855

housewives are our true nation builders.  They work unheralded quietly at home, taking care of the family and children, bringing them up to be good Singapore citizens which our nation so much depends and relies.  I think at the next Budget, the Minister should reward them with something.

 

     The second group is the elderly contract workers.  Almost every time I am at the Changi Airport coming back or leaving for an overseas trip, I am confronted by elderly workers there, pushing their trolleys.  They complain to me about their work. 

 

 

They are contract workers and do not receive CPF and other perks which other workers normally receive.  I hope the Minister can also look into their plight and reward them.  After all, these elderly workers have given a lifetime of work to society and, in their twilight years, they should be given something back. 

 

     Through the Workfare and various CPF changes, the CPF balances of most workers will increase, but many are worried that their savings in Medisave are not enough to meet their medical needs.  In fact, my feedback tells me that there are many workers whose Medisave accounts are already depleted.  Can the Minister do something for these aged poor patients who need medical help badly, maybe to top up their Medisave accounts whenever they fall below $2,000?  I hope the Minister will look into this as the insufficiency of funds in their Medisave accounts is widespread.

     The Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Community Development, Youth and Sports (Mr Teo Ser Luck): Mr Speaker, Sir, thank you for the opportunity to speak on the Budget. 

 

     First, I would like to commend the Second Minister and his team for a great

Column: 1856

effort in coming out with a Budget that has made some very bold moves.  It is daring in expanding help and keeping Singapore competitive, but I would not say that it has shifted in our fundamental principles of making sure that the needy get help and making sure that those who can help themselves would get help from the Government.  What it has done is that it has led the way in showing what needs to be done in our current circumstances with a sense of urgency. 

 

     Some say this is a hong bao Budget.  If that is the case, the hong bao comes in different shapes and sizes, some big, some small.  the difference is that you get hong bao only once a year for Chinese New Year although I am no longer entitled to that.  But, in this case, the hong bao Budget is for the whole year round.  So, when you give the hong bao, you cannot take it back and it is for the entire year.  You distribute hong bao throughout the year. 

 

     As such, the hong bao must go to the right persons with the right amount and for the right reasons.  So, the signal and the message must also be sent out very correctly and clearly.  This is because, after the Budget was announced, like the rest, I was very excited, I was glad of the outcome until two young students 16 years of age asked me a question.  They have kept track of the Budget announcement.  I think that is a very good thing to do.  They start young.  But they asked, "Mr Teo, everybody seems to be getting some bonus.  What about us?"  At that point, I was hoping that they were not going to ask for baby bonus at the age of 16.  They said, "We work part-time and our income is below $1,500.  Should we not get financial help to have more pocket money?" 

 

     Of course, I went on to explain the principles of the Budget and why and where the help is going to and what is in

Column: 1857

it for them, which is in education and their investments, and that whatever is for their parents would be channelled down to them as well.  But they gave me the puzzled look and I hope that they actually understood what I was telling them.  However, it is not the first time I get asked, because when the Progress Package was given out, I was asked a similar question by a 17-year-old polytechnic student, ie, where would he stand?  Would he get his Progress Package? 

 

     I am not suggesting that we should give less.  In fact, I think we should give to the needy, the bottom percentile, but we should give out appropriately, send the right message to the young that we have a good Government not in giving you the fish but in teaching you how to fish and, when you cannot find the fish, we will help buy some for you for a limited period of time while you keep trying to find the fish.  It is important in the Budget of knowing that you have to earn before you take.  So we do not want to build a generation of takers.  We need a generation of earners who earn their keep, and givers, those who are willing to share.

 

     This Budget is no doubt generous.  Because it is generous, more are now looking for what is in for them and the size of their hong bao.  I think it is important to note that this Budget is about giving you a helping hand so that you can help yourself.  And it is not just a giveaway.  We should really avoid for the Budget to becoming a real real hong bao.

 

     All said, this Budget is about change.  It changes and challenges the thinking and rationale of how we view the future and how we prepare for the challenges.  It is trying to help us not to be too conservative.  It talks about opening up, evolving and following the pace of the market.  That, in itself, is to me a

Column: 1858

fundamental shift in the thoughts.  There are four major elements, namely, GST increase/offset packages, CPF, Workfare and corporate taxation.

 

     The Budget looks after the needy and poor with GST offset packages and a string of assistance.  No one would have liked to pay more.  But what other alternatives for revenue sources?  Direct taxes?  That would not happen.  More are asking for reduction, so there is no way we could increase, and I certainly would not ask for it.  If we are asking to tap on our reserves, I would question, is that a prudent approach?  I think the question here is, if we could not obtain enough from other sources, how much do we exactly need, and is GST increase the only way?

 

     Workfare is a good scheme.  It makes sure you are self-reliant with a job so that you can be financially independent in the long term before being rewarded with a Workfare bonus.  The question again is:  with Workfare Income Supplement scheme and Workfare, would a worker be encouraged to stay at $1,500 and below and not wanting to go beyond that?  But Workfare's intention is to help encourage you to stay employed longer.  My only concern is that it may motivate an individual a different way.  So, we will have to ensure that the signal is sent out correctly.

 

     By increasing CPF contribution, we recognise that the economy is now doing well and we have to reward the workers who can face the future with confidence.  I refuse to believe that CPF resuming to 14.5% would increase the cost of business as the economy is getting better, and it is an important strategy of talent retention rather than losing them because, when we lose them, it costs more to hire them again or to hire an additional person.

 

     Reducing the corporate tax rate to keep us competitive, but that comes with

Column: 1859

a price.  We lose a revenue source, we need to find a replacement.  Like some Members of this House who asked if increasing GST or indirect taxes in support of keeping us competitive, how long can that be sustained and what is our threshold level?  My question is: even with the lowering of corporate tax, how attractive is this for investments and investors and how long can we maintain this competitiveness?  All this would require a growing and stable economy, continuing foreign direct investments, and good governance of the funds in order to sustain the competitiveness. 

 

     The reduction from 20% to 18% attempts to keep us competitive for foreign direct investments (FDIs), the partial tax exemption for the growth of SMEs, and the more important message is to use this gain for the small and medium enterprises to venture outwards, and the 80:20 rule exemption attracts financial flow of philanthropy operations.  Are these attractive enough compared to the other countries?  We make many comparisons with Hong Kong.  Hong Kong's corporate tax rate is 17.5%.  We have now brought it down to 18%, and today Hong Kong is going to make some new announcements.  For SMEs with $500,000 chargeable income, the effective tax rate is 12.5%.  For income tax rate, it is generally lower in Singapore.  But for the really rich and the senior talents, Singapore is higher compared to Hong Kong.

 

     But we have been voted the country with the lowest risk to do business in.  With all this, we would have thought surely we are now ahead.  But I would just say that we have only levelled up with Hong Kong.  We have definitely put in the hard work and effort to make Singapore more successful.  But the fact remains that we do not have a mass market behind us.  Hong Kong has it.  It has China.  At the end of the day, to any business person or company, proximity to the target market is critical.  Foreign direct investment in

Column: 1860

China is around $70 billion.  In Singapore, it is $8 billion. 

 

     I had a personal experience when I was living in China and Hong Kong.  I had to recommend a location of an operations centre for a multinational company.  It was between Singapore, Hong Kong and Shanghai.  So we went through due diligence, calculated the costs.  Singapore came up cost lowest; Hong Kong, salary and labour cost higher; and Shanghai, there was an uncertainty on infrastructure and the availability of talent.  So, on paper, it looks like we have the lowest cost.  But the investor chose Hong Kong because it is still closer to China, and I saw many of my friends lost their jobs. 

 

     But I am not even going to suggest to continue pushing down the corporate tax rate or pushing up indirect taxes like GST.  But then again, we never know.  Singapore is so affected by external factors that it may become inevitable to keep corporate tax rate lower and lower whilst indirect taxes may just go up to replace the loss of revenue.  We need a really effective way to manage this and decide what is the strategic direction in moving forward.  Should we just concentrate on pricing, which is the tax rate, or we have to concentrate on the product, the kind of investment that would be put in into Singapore? 

 

     So, Singapore has been competitive in its positioning as a hub.  If we are to compete as a gateway or a hub, we need to identify which market we are positioning as a hub in service to, ie, which area.  If we still position ourselves as an Asia Pacific hub, I would advise not to, because there does not seem to be any more competitive advantage as an Asia Pacific hub.  In the north, we have Shanghai, Hong Kong or other first-tier or second-tier cities of China doing better today that can serve as a North Asia hub.  So, you fly in your cargoes, bring your investment in close to the target market,

Column: 1861

you do not really need to pass through here.  And if we try to be a Southeast Asia hub, then it is important for the countries of ASEAN and Southeast Asia to come together as an integrated market to be effective.  But the way things are going at the moment, I think it will take a while, especially when Indonesia and Thailand are both major markets of ASEAN.  Then again, even if we do come together, is it sufficient for the growth we are looking for? 

 

     So I would suggest we should be a hub to the world in different sectors.  I think that is the direction the Government is taking today.  It is the right approach.  We have to be unique, special and, if possible, be the first-mover or innovator.  We cannot just talk about the current life-science investment or biomedical science sectors all the time.  We need to reinvent ourselves even in sectors that already exist, eg, IT, logistics, education, health, tourism, energy - lots of opportunities.  We have to keep innovating and take risks, trial and change.

 

     We have to make sure we secure air rights to key countries.  We have to be connected to all major continents like a spider web where we are right in the middle and can reach any place, do business in any country with ease, using Singapore as the stepping-board. 

 

     People make the difference, so we need to have a good mix of both local and foreign talents in this country, if we ever want to be called a hub.  Like many Members of this House, we need to retain the best local talents, but we also need the best foreign talents from all over the world to be competitive, because there are some skills sets that are just not available here.  We need to learn from the skilled professionals around the world.  We know that, if that is successful, we would have created jobs and opportunities. 

Column: 1862

There is no other way to be competitive but to accept the fact that having foreign talents is necessary.  Attract them to come.  If that means lowering income tax, we have to consider it. 

 

     Singapore must be positioned to the world as a whole package, ie, people, knowledge, infrastructure, stability, a lot of excitement, buzzing and cost-effective to operate and live in, and risk-free. 

 

     While the environment may be risk-free, the Government or the public sector, I would hope, should be expected to take some risks and change in its approach towards investing in new sectors or projects.  We have to be open to let the private sector or even the people sector take the lead while the Government supports and facilitates.  It

 

 

cannot be leading and trying to do everything all the time.  You can also not pretend to be experts in all fields. Most importantly, it should not set up road blocks and make the process to success that much more difficult.  I have said this before. We can always depend on ROIs.  But in some ventures, there are just no ROIs or NPVs or track record to talk about. So we should not be too quick to jump to conclusion or turn down opportunities.  Who would have thought YouTube or Goggle or some other companies are so successful today and not have been a sure winner when they started out? A straight "A" student may not necessarily turn out to be an ace corporate executive.  So I say, let the expert do the job.  Let the private sector take the lead, if necessary, and we will support them because we cannot be everywhere. 

 

    All that said, this is an all-encompassing Budget. That is a change catalyst.  It paints a vision and charts the direction for change that instils confidence in all of us about the future of Singapore.  It may be bold to some extent, but it is necessary and long overdue.  If we do not do that, we risk being not able to catch

Column: 1863

up with other countries in the region.  It could be Hong Kong today but it could be Shanghai tomorrow or central and East Asian countries' emerging economies could be next to take away the business from us.  But we can take heart that we are in the right direction with this Budget and there is no turning back as we embark on this new journey.

      This Budget hopes that Singaporeans will have more confidence and be optimistic about our future.  The Government may still make some slight adjustments in this aspect in our Budget, to ensure that job opportunities are available and so on.  We hope that more opportunities will be created to allow our corporations to move outwards when our economic outlook is good and economic cooperation with many countries is also improving.  But we do understand that Singapore is very much open to external influence, so we need to continue to work hard and re-invent ourselves, and increase our wages and foreign investments in Singapore.

     The first two groups of stakeholders are already receiving a fair amount of proactive attention from the Government and, in the case of companies, Government agencies, such as IE Singapore and the Economic Development Board.  The 2007 Budget Statement, for example, has introduced a number of very helpful measures to assist low-wage Singaporean workers who may have been adversely affected by globalisation.  These include restructuring the CPF, Workfare and the GST offset package.  These measures will help to build a more inclusive society and promote social cohesion and harmony which are essential, if we are to stay focused on implementing our economic strategy and not be distracted by social tensions and instability.

 

     But what about attention to the third group of stakeholders?  Have we done enough to ensure that we have sufficient new talent to energise the economy and enable us to go the full distance? 

 

     Sir, my next point concerns the third stakeholder group, ie, the non-Singaporeans.  This is not an easy group to deal with because of the diversity within its ranks - ethnic, economic, cultural and mindset.  Included in this group are the traditional "expatriates" who are brought to Singapore by their employers usually for fixed periods to

Column: 1887

serve a particular need.  These individuals are usually well taken care of by their companies and enjoy a wide array of benefits, such as housing, schooling for their children, transport and home leave allowances.  In many cases, they also get the benefit of "tax equalisation" which effectively shelters them from differences and changes to the Singapore tax rate relative to their home country.

 

     However, a growing group of foreigners who are now living and working in Singapore do not belong to this financially privileged expatriate group.  Who are they?  Well, they are highly skilled individuals who have made a conscious personal decision to come and work in Singapore.  They have picked Singapore over their home country or other competing locations.  This group of foreigners is often described as "expatriates on local terms" because they enjoy little or no fringe benefits.  They have to take care of their own housing and schooling needs for their children.  They do not enjoy any tax equalisation and they have to provide for their own retirement.

 

     Why are they here?  I guess it is another facet of globalisation.  Talent is mobile and moves to centres where there are good career opportunities and which afford an attractive lifestyle.  Singapore has been able to attract this talent pool from all parts of the world - the UK, Europe, Australia, New Zealand, South and Southeast Asia, China and even as far as South America and Africa.

 

     Why are they important to us?  I submit to you, Sir, that our ability to attract such talented individuals and successfully integrate them both in the workplace and in our society is a critical success factor if we are to grow our economy at a consistently healthy rate.  Simply put, Singapore has a lot of homegrown talent but not enough if we want to remain competitive in this highly

Column: 1888

competitive globalised economy.  And due to our lack of natural resources and small hinterland, we cannot afford not to be competitive.

 

     Sir, the shortage of skills and talents is one of the main threats to our long-term growth and prospects.  This is the view of a majority of CEOs who participated in one of the latest global CEO surveys which sought the opinions of more than a thousand distinguished CEOs from 50 countries, including companies in our region.

 

     The worrying news is that the competition for such talent is global and fierce and getting fiercer by the day.  Some years ago, when my firm placed recruitment advertisements in regional newspapers, we were able to draw several hundreds of applicants.  Today, the same advertisements have far fewer applicants.  This is because we are no longer competing only with cities such as London, Hong Kong, San Jose or Sydney for talent.  New centres, such as Shanghai, Bangalore and Dubai, have emerged.  In time to come, other cities in Eastern Europe, the Middle East, India and East Asia will all be competing with us for the same talent pool.

 

     It was interesting to note the comments of the Minister for National Development which were reported in the press on 10th February 2007 and in Parliament yesterday.  These suggested that, according to the Concept Plan, Singapore's population could be 6.5 million.  This may be just the number that planners are using to base their projections for planning purposes.  But it does represent a significant increase from the 4.5 million we have today. 

 

     Based on the current birth rate of about 1.2, compared to a rate of 2.1 that is required to keep the population of Singaporeans steady, it is clear that the bulk of any future growth in our

Column: 1889

population would have to be imported.  So the group that I mentioned actually falls into two subgroups, namely, those who are here and whom we presumably want to keep, and new talent from overseas that we have to attract to Singapore.  So the message is clear.  Not only will we have to fight to get the talent in the first place, we will also have to find ways of making sure it does not leave.

 

     Sir, but the 2007 Budget has virtually nothing to offer this group of individuals who, I believe, are important stakeholders and partners in our economic journey. 

 

     A reduction in personal income tax rates would have been viewed positively by the group who are already here.  They are faced with having to cope with an increase in the cost of living, particularly a steep increase in residential rental rates.  Soon, they will be hit with the full force of the GST hike, with no corresponding offsets, nor will they benefit from the increase in employers' CPF contributions.

 

     Sir, perhaps, at this juncture, the Government feels that Singapore is still able to attract its fair share of talent from overseas and there is no necessity for any fiscal incentives or encouragement.  This may well be true.  After all, we are a competitive destination, with an excellent infrastructure, a pleasure pollution-free environment, a low crime rate, all of which contribute to a comfortable and gracious lifestyle. 

 

     But in my view, there are some features which we must add to this admittedly attractive environment, in order to keep us ahead of the increasing competition for foreign talent.  Low personal tax rates are just one of them.  But the cornerstone of any strategy aimed at attracting foreign talent for the long term has to be to create an environment which focuses on the longer term needs of this group.  In short, they need long-

Column: 1890

term financial security and the fiscal support to have families, which is now only available in respect of Singaporean children.  Employer-sponsored pension arrangements are something many of them will have taken as a given.  But they arrive here to find that there is very little available, as far as long-term security is concerned.

 

     In this context, it is easy to say, "Yes, but if they become Singaporeans, then they get all these benefits, CPF included".  The point this misses, as most long-term "expatriates" will tell you, is that Singapore grows on you.  Quite often, they were just passing through with no plans to stay, or were here for a defined short term.  Forcing them into decisions early before they have had a chance to feel comfortable here in general and, in particular, asking them to give away their links (emotional and physical) with home, namely, their passport, is more likely to frighten them off, rather than encourage them to make plans for a longer-term association.  There needs to be something that fills the transition, and something significant.

 

     Because our "local" foreign talent pool happens to be outside the political mainstream, it should not mean that their voices should go unheard.  By listening to them, we not only help them to make the decision to stay, but we also learn what is likely to attract others to choose Singapore in the future.  At present, and as far as I am aware, we do not have a mechanism for the Government to obtain formal and regular feedback on matters affecting this stakeholder group.  Given the strategic importance of the group to Singapore's future growth and prosperity, we should seriously consider setting up formal channels for regular feedback so that appropriate action can be taken on a timely basis.

Column: 1891

transient migrants.  Instead, we should make them feel as comfortable as possible from the outset by being inclusive in the way our policies are framed and in our informal dealings and mindset.  This will give these individuals the confidence and courage to make Singapore their permanent home and help attract the steady stream of new talent from overseas that we need, if we are to achieve our economic growth targets.

 

     Sir, I do not pretend to have all the solutions to these issues, but what is clear is that they need to be moved up the rankings of importance.  Singapore has been second to none in planning and putting in place its infrastructural "hardware", but we need to ensure that our software continues to be best in class because, ultimately, knowledge, innovation and creativity will be the difference between the winners and losers of tomorrow.

 

     Sir, I support the motion.

The larger the coefficient, the more unequal the income distribution.  In Singapore, the Gini coefficient rose from 0.442 in 2000 to 0.472 last year.  This is based on income from work per household member. It is sobering to note that we have a higher Gini coefficient than the US figure of 0.469 in 2005.  This would give us a rough idea of where we stand in terms of income inequality on the global scale. If we factored in the Progress Package last year which was skewed towards the lower-income, our Gini coefficient was lowered to 0.439.  In other words, it narrowed the income gap.  I would expect our Gini coefficient this year to also be moderated because of our Workfare and the GST offset package but the question that we have to ask ourselves is, what would be an acceptable income gap in this society.  What degree of income inequality can we tolerate?  Is there a Gini coefficient number or a range that we should aim for or work towards from the scale of zero to one: is there a golden mean?

 

     It is important for us to come to a consensus on this because if we want to commit funds to WIS to make sure that the income gap is narrowed, we must have a certain goal as to what level of inequality we want to diminish.  If we want to commit additional funds every year, it means that more and more revenue would have to be sought for it as the gap will widen every year as globalisation picks up pace.  It has to be a sustained effort to keep looking for funds

to sustain our WIS which will increase over the years as the income gap increases.

Column: 1908

     Dr Ong Seh Hong (Marine Parade): Mdm Deputy Speaker, I support the Budget Statement. However, please allow me to raise some concerns on this otherwise celebratory Budget.

 

    Madam, I am concerned with the Government's intention to widen the definition of the Net Investment Income (NII) to include capital gain.  The details of the definition of this capital gain to be included in NII and what portion is allowed to be used has yet to be announced.  Nevertheless, I urge the Government to "sai si ", to think thrice and to move very prudently on this matter.

 

   We have always guarded our national reserve very carefully.  Only until a few years ago, we started to allow the use of NII.  Even then, the Government has adhered to a very prudent and conservative spending of up to 50% of NII contributions.  Moreover, the NII definition is limited to dividends and interest income.  The usage of NII has so far enabled us to avoid budget deficits for many years. This amounted to about 1.6% of our GDP in the past five years.

 

    Madam, the policy of using only half of this interest and dividend income

Column: 1931

without touching the capital gain, though conservative, has allowed our assets to continue to grow in tandem with the growth of the underlying asset class as well as the economy.  Once we start to touch on the capital gains, the situation will change.

 

    If my grandfather had the foresight, which he had not, to buy a 20,000 square foot land in Bukit Timah at less than $2 per square foot some 40-50 years ago, the land would have fetched me at least $10 million now. This is a conservative estimate.  The capital gain would be $9,960,000.  If I were allowed to spend the capital gain, the original dollar of $40,000 would not buy me any property at all.  Even if I were to spend only half of the amount, the remaining $5 million will not get me anything close to what I have just sold. Even with $10 million, I may not be able to get back the same type of property of similar size and location, especially so if the economy is booming.

 

    Madam, if we allow capital gain to be spent away, how do we prevent any irresponsible government in future, to sell away our long-term held assets, in order to realise the capital gain so that they can spend them on some of the promises they gave to their electorate?

 

    For more volatile assets like equity, the problem could be even worse.  Let us say, in a market bull run, up until these two days where the market has major corrections, the price of some blue chip counters, I was told, have gone up a few times, three or four times over the last one year.  Let us say, we bought a counter at $1 and we sold it at $2. When the price goes up to $4, we will not be able to get back also the same quantity of shares that we held previously.  And then, we may lose in the long-term gains for this asset.

 

    I do not know what is the exact portfolio mix of our Singapore reserves,

Column: 1932

but the shear size of it implies that they must have been well allocated and diversified across different asset classes and also spread over many geographic regions.  With this well diversified portfolio, some of our investments will do well this year and another set of investment probably will perform well the next year.  Overall, we should achieve a constant long-term growth.  However, if we always take profit whenever there are capital gains and spend away all or part of the capital gains, then over the longer term, we will not be able to enjoy the consistent growth that we are used to and our "real" asset value, net of inflation, may remain stagnant or even diminish over the years.

 

     There is also a technical problem on which currency we should calculate our capital gain.  Should it be Singapore dollars or any international currency? Either one would have its problem. For example, our investment in a foreign currency would appreciate in Singapore dollar term if our Singapore dollar weakens. Should this be considered as a capital gain?  I will argue against this.  In fact, a currency quite often reflects the strength of its underlying economy as well as its reserve backing.  If our dollar weakens, it probably means that our economy is not doing so well.  In fact, there is more reason that we should not take profit and we should preserve this asset in order to give a stronger backing to our currency.

 

    Next, I would also like to touch on protection of some of these strategic investments.  Some investments may be made for strategic reasons and should be held for long-term national interest.  However, the personnel in charge of our investment may change over time while our strategic interests probably do not change so often.  Allowing capital gain to be realised and spent away may also be very tempting for future governments to lose sight of our national strategic interest and sell off these strategic investments.

 

Column: 1933

    Madam, I understand our Government will need to find new sources of funds other than from taxation in order to fund all these various new programmes and initiatives to keep our economy competitive while helping our people.  However, there is a Chinese saying, "fu bu guo san dai ", which means the wealth in the family does not go beyond three generations.  Many businessmen always lament that the first generation works very hard to accumulate their wealth, to make the first pot of gold.  And the second generation will continue to work to grow it. Then comes the third generation who spends and splurges it away and wipes out what the family has accumulated.

 

    I know this is definitely not the intention of our Finance Minister and the Government to open the floodgate for our future generations of leaders to wipe out our national reserves.  But in view of the potential downfalls I have just alluded to,  I urge the Government to seriously reconsider this proposition to include capital gain in the NII.

 

   If the Government still wants to push ahead, I would like to make the following suggestions:

 

   First, to limit the capital gains to those investments made during the term of the government and the gain that is made during the term so that the government of any term will not be able to take profit of good investments made by previous governments.

 

    Second, to set a minimum rate at which the total asset size must grow before any gain can be realised. This minimum rate can be pegged at a certain percentage, say, 2%, above the inflation rate.

 

    Third, to set the maximum amount of NII that can be used in any one year,

Column: 1934

expressed as a percentage of the total asset size. That, we can work out the number.

   I have three more suggestions:

 

    Fourth, to exclude capital gains due to fluctuation of currency exchange rate. 

 

    Fifth, we need to draw up a list of strategic investments to be protected.

     Dr Lily Neo (Jalan Besar): Mdm Deputy Speaker, the Second Finance Minister, in his Budget speech, said that we have to prepare now for the challenges of an ageing population and must ensure the well-being of the senior citizens. Column: 1935

internationally-renowned. The PAP Government has also proven to be capable in dealing with crises and challenges over the years.  I believe that we shall do just as well in this new challenge to prepare for an ageing population.

 

     The issue of an ageing population is not new, and it is one that many developed and developing nations are facing and will one day have to address.  The impending demographic shift in Singapore is alarming.  Our over-65 population is projected to grow by 372% from 2000 to 2030 - faster than in other ageing societies, such as Japan, 54%; Germany, 63%; and China, 170%.  Life expectancy will rise by some four years by 2020 and 10 years by 2050. 

 

     There are already indications from the ground that these concerns will soon take centre stage. The next generation of seniors will have varying needs and aspirations, and it is this growing lobbying group that will invariably have an exerting effect on many of our policies. 

 

 

     I wish to highlight six areas that require our immediate attention.

 

Finance

 

     Mr first point is on retirement financing.  The current CPF system may require revisions to cater to the needs of retirees.  Our society is rapidly evolving towards an ageing population, smaller family sizes and thus fewer children to depend on, and higher dependency ratio.  In 2005, only four in 10 Singaporeans aged 55 have the mandatory amount in their CPF accounts.

 

     There may be a need to implement instruments to supplement the current CPF system.  Of immediate concern is the lack of a viable compulsory insurance scheme for Singaporeans for retirement purposes.

 

Column: 1936

      I would like to suggest a mandatory universal annuity insurance scheme to ensure that all Singaporeans are self-reliant, and able to provide for basic retirement needs.  This scheme makes it mandatory for Singaporeans to pay for a universal insurance fund using a percentage of their CPF.  Members are already allowed to use their CPF for investments, housing purchases and MediShield.

 

     This scheme establishes a common insurance fund that is redistributive in nature.  Contributions could be progressive in nature, and lower-income groups could receive Government top-ups to fund their contribution.  The advantages of such a scheme are better economies of scale, lower premiums and higher pay-outs.

 

Employment

 

     My second point is on continuing employment.  We should consider raising the current retirement age to 65 and explore avenues for upgrading and employment for older workers.  There are benefits in retaining older Singaporeans in the workforce for both employers and employees.  Employees remain socially, physically and mentally active, and continue to be financially self-sufficient.  Additionally, more than half of Singapore companies surveyed agreed that the retirement of older workers means the loss of valuable skills and knowledge.  There is further evidence to show that while there is some decline in mental and physical capacities between the ages of 50 and 70, it is minute and may be compensated for by changing the working environment and working practices.  HSBC's recent Future of Retirement Survey also revealed that two-thirds of Singaporeans believe they should bear the financial cost of their own retirement.  These indicators support calls to extend the compulsory retirement age and to nurture lifelong employability of workers.

 

Column: 1937

Healthcare

 

     My third point is on the need for strategies to ensure the health quality of Singaporeans.  Increased life expectancies due to advances in modern medicine will pose new challenges to our healthcare system.  It is imperative that proactive measures be taken now to address these challenges.

 

     There are a few key areas to improve on.   First, we may need to review the 3-M system in light of extended life expectancies.  Increased public awareness of this system will help address public concerns about healthcare affordability.

 

     Second, we could place greater emphasis on preventive care, particularly in the prevention of common chronic diseases.  We could also ensure better care for newly afflicted patients to prevent full-blown complications.

 

     Third, we need to look at developing a home-care system which is currently non-existent.  This would help many semi-ambulant patients receive care and treatment in their homes.

 

     Fourth, we need to manage and alleviate increasing demand for and dependence on acute hospital beds.  Improvements and enhancements to step down care and community care may be viable solutions.

 

     Finally, we may need to look at ways to improve the capabilities and capacities of geriatric medicine to meet the needs of this changing demographic.

 

Housing

 

     My fourth issue deals with the need to revise current housing concepts and policies to cater for the elderly.

     We could also look at increasing the number of studio apartments.  These apartments are already in greater demand and will continue to be amongst the elderly.  Rental HDB flats will continue to be popular, particularly with the lower-income group.

 

     A two-pronged approach  could also be useful to ensure that both retirement funding and housing needs are taken care of.  This could be done by improving the current reverse mortgaging scheme to provide liquidity for retirement and, at the same time, provide affordable housing at retirement.

 

Social activity

     Mr Ong Kian Min (Tampines): Mdm Deputy Speaker, I support the Budget Statement delivered by the Second Minister for Finance.  In view of the time constraint, I will not repeat the commendations and the issues that have already been raised, but go straight to the one point that I would like to make.

     We are doing much to help raise the income of low-wage workers with schemes like Workfare.  But salary is only one aspect.  While the low-wage workers rely on his salary, the top earners have two income drivers or income streams.  The first is their salary income that they earn from their work, and the second is the returns from their investments or the assets that they have accumulated. With the stock market having risen to record levels last week and the increase in property prices at the top end, the top earners have become much richer in the last year or two. And I believe our Gini coefficient that Ms Irene Ng mentioned just now is even larger because in Singapore, capital gains on investments are not treated as taxable personal income.

 

     Madam, I have an analogy.  It is like two power-boats moving on the water, not the sampan or sailboat that Ms Irene Ng mentioned just now, but two power-boats.  The power-boat of the top earners has two high-performance outboard motors.  The first is the wages they earn which go up at a much faster rate with higher increments year on year.  The second is the investment returns they get from their capital and assets which increase at a compound rate year after year.  These two income engines power their boat forward - both engines not

Column: 1942

only churning at full throttle but increasing their horsepower output continuously year after year.  Whereas the power-boat of a low-income earner has only one outboard motor, which is the wages he earns, struggling to maintain his power output with small annual increments.  And maybe another low-performance motor producing meagre returns from a small capital.  How can the income gap not widen? How can the wealth gap not widen? the returns from our CPF?  I am a voluntary Executive Committee member of the Financial Planning Association of Singapore and this subject is close to my heart.

 

     Warren Buffett, who was a Great Depression baby born in the year 1930, started with almost nothing, but he became the second richest man in the world that he is today by growing his capital at an annual compound rate of return of 24.7% over the last 50 years.  I just want to refer to the example Dr Ong Seh Hong mentioned just now of his grandfather.  He wished his grandfather had the foresight to invest $40,000 at two dollars per square foot in a piece of land in Bukit Timah which after 40 years today would be worth $10 million, and that is an increase of 250 times.  But if his grandfather had the foresight to invest with Warren Buffett 40 years ago, his $40,000 would have become $218 million today.  So that is the example of the power of compound interest.  So just imagine again, if every Singaporean on turning 21 years old gets a sum of $1,000 earning 24% returns per year compounded, by the time 40 years later when he retires at the age of 62, his initial capital of $1,000 would have grown to $5.5 million, surely more than sufficient to meet all his retirement needs.  In such a situation, I do not think we have many of the problems of a greying population that we face today.  Now, perhaps, we think the returns of 24% per year is wishful thinking.  Temasek Holdings, in 32 years, grew its total portfolio value from S$350 million to S$129 billion (that is, from S$350 to S$129,000 million) but even with new capital injections along the way, I believe the compounded annual growth rate of Temasek Holdings was comfortably double digit.  Private bankers conservatively are expecting to get for their high net worth clients 8% to 10% a year for a balanced portfolio.  Top pension funds

     Secondly, CPF Board may say that it publishes the Semi Annual CPFIS Funds Report which CPF members should read to educate themselves and to be more aware.  I would like to ask how many of us here have actually read that report and, anyway, when I read it, it says it only serves as a simplified guide, it is not designed to offer investment advice of any kind, and, in fact, it cautions those who require investment guidance to engage their own investment adviser.

 

     Madam, the difference between 4% and 10% per year may seem small but over the long term of 40 years to retirement, an initial sum of $10,000 at 4% per year will only become $48,000, but at 10% per year compounded will see it growing to $453,000, almost 10 times more.  This will surely make a very significant and meaningful difference to our retirement sum.  I would like to, therefore, urge the Government to restructure the CPF to go beyond paying interest on our CPF savings and to take on a more active role in managing our assets more like a pension or investment fund manager.
