5.55 pm

 

     The Minister, Prime Minister's Office (Mr Lim Swee Say): Mdm Deputy Speaker, from the labour movement's point of view, this year's Budget is a win-win Budget.  The cut of two percentage points in corporate tax rate is a win for businesses.  So this is a pro-business Budget because with the reduction in corporate tax, companies will have more profit and, as a result, be able to not just reward the workers better but, more importantly, also invest for the future and continue to grow.

Column: 1947

 

     At the same time, this Budget is also a win for the workers because the 1.5 percentage point restoration of employees' CPF and the introduction of Workfare as a permanent feature of our social safety net are important for the long-term welfare of the workers.  So it is a pro-worker budget as well.

 

     Last but not least, this is also a pro-Singapore Budget because, with the increase in GST, the Government will be able to do an even better job in ensuring that the Singapore economy will be competitive and the society will be cohesive.  Therefore, the labour movement welcomes fully this pro-business, pro-worker, and pro-Singapore Budget.

 

     Having said that, the question in our minds is: does this mean that, with such a good Budget, all our problems are solved?  Does it mean that the problems of low-wage workers would disappear?  Does it mean that the economy of Singapore will always continue to grow?  Does it mean that Singapore will always make progress as a successful nation?  The answer is probably "no".  No matter how good the Budget is, it is only part of the solution, it is not the entire solution.

 

     So I would like to talk about, from the labour movement's point of view, how workers should look at this Budget and how to work together to achieve even better outcomes, better still, the best outcome for all Singaporean, for all workers.

 

     Sir, Bangkok is the spa capital of the world.  There is a street in Bangkok, a very vibrant place. On that street alone there must be about 20 to 30 spas. The place is very vibrant, especially at night.  You can choose any of these spas, you get good services from foot massage to body massage. They charge 200 bahts per hour, about eight Singapore dollars an hour, and the place is very vibrant because many customers go there since it is competitive and convenient.  But yet,

Column: 1948

not too far away, if you take a cab, ten minutes away, there is another cluster of spas.  Customers go there not because it is more convenient and better, but because it is cheaper since they charge only 90 bahts per hour.  So for customers who believe in "cheaper is better", they take a taxi to go to that place and they pay 90 bahts an hour.  Yet, ten minutes away in the other direction, there is another cluster of spas. They compete differently because charging 200 bahts per hour means the profit margin is small. They will have to depend a lot on volume. So these spas decide to compete differently.  They offer massage with something special - the room, decor, music, food and ambience are fantastic. For that, they charge 1,000 bahts per hour. In other words, you look at the spa capital of the world, they have spas competing on 200 bahts for the mass market, 90 bahts for the “cheaper is better” type of customers, or 1,000 bahts per hour on the basis of differentiation.

 

     In our local terminology using our local language, we describe the 200 bahts-per-hour spa which is based on convenience, competition, high volume with low profit margin as "giam tan" business.   "Giam tan" means profit margin is small but you survive on big volume.  For the 90 bahts-per-hour kind of spas, they call it the "pai tan" or the "bo tan" type of business.  And for the 1,000 bahts, I think you have guessed it, it is called the "ho tan" business.  So when we ask our local businessmen what business they are in, they will say either "ho tan", "pai tan" or "giam tan".  Of course, the management consultants cannot make money if they use terms such as "giam tan", 'ho tan" or "pai tan".  So they come out with very creative terminology.  They describe the 200 bahts type as "blue sky economy" - under the blue sky, crowded place, highly competitive, low margin, big volume.  And those competing on low cost, low price, they call them the "red ocean".  And those going for the high margin, they call them

Column: 1949

the "blue ocean".  Why "blue ocean"?  Because the "blue ocean" is a beautiful ocean, not too crowded. If you can survive in the blue ocean, you have the whole catchment to yourself.  Why "red ocean"?  Because in "red ocean", people undercut each other, they engage in cut-throat business. When you cut the throat, blood will flow and the blue ocean will turn to red ocean.

 

     In Bangkok, the spa capital of the world, the three types of economy co-exist - "red ocean", "blue sky", "blue ocean".  In fact, not just in Bangkok, all over the world, these three categories of economy co-exist. In Singapore, it is also the same.   

 

 

     Some of our companies are competing under the "blue sky".  Our factory workers, for example, for a long time, their wages have been stuck at about $1,000 per month.  Sometimes, the workers will ask the union leaders, "Union leaders, can you do something for us?  Raise our wages."  But we could not. Why? Because workers in Singapore are paid $1,000 per month.  Workers in China are also paid $1,000 per month.  But the difference is that ours is 1,000 Singapore dollars and theirs is 1,000 renminbi.  After conversion to US dollars, we are about five times more expensive, in terms of labour cost per hour.  As a result, because of the "blue sky" competition, just like the many spas in that little street, nobody dares to raise their charges beyond 200 bahts because when you do that, you will be out of business.  It is the same thing.  Wages in Singapore for the rank and file workers, for some of them at least, when they are caught in this very intense "blue sky" competition, their wages cannot go up.

 

     Yet, there is another group of workers whose wages also cannot go up.  Sometimes the wages may even drop

Column: 1950

because they are the "red ocean" workers. Yesterday, several fellow MPs talked about their concern for cheap sourcing.  With more companies embarking on outsourcing, and if more and more of them were to engage in cheap sourcing, then over time, more and more of our workers could be caught by this cut-throat competition and, as a result, become workers sinking or floating in the "red ocean".  Because of this very intense "blue sky" competition and "red ocean" competition, we have now institutionalise Workfare, making it the fourth pillar of our social safety net.  This is the reason why the labour movement welcome this very much.  When the Prime Minister announced the setting up of Workfare as a permanent feature, the labour movement cheered.  We cheer because on the ground, we can feel the pain suffered by these low-wage workers and we believe that the Workfare as the fourth pillar of safety net will come as a relief to many of them.

 

     Having said that, over the last few weeks, there have been a lot of discussions about what is the purpose of Workfare and why do we tie Workfare to Medisave?  Why do we tie Workfare to CPF?  Why not let informal workers enjoy the Workfare in the form of cash instead of Medisave? The argument is that low-wage workers need the dollars today, not tomorrow.

 

     The labour movement strongly support and are 100% behind this linkage of the Workfare to Medisave and CPF.  Let me explain. Instead of talking to you in theory and concept, let me give you two real case situations and make a comparison.  There is a gentleman, his name is Mr Prunari, 46 years old.  He used to work as a general labourer with CPF.  Until two years, he left the job, and today, he is working as an informal worker.  He works and he receives pay, but he does not pay CPF.  He does not make CPF contribution.  He does not make Medisave contribution. 

Column: 1951

Every dollar he earns, he brings home.  He is happy with that. But now, he has other problems.  He is living in a 4-room flat together with his wife and two children.  His wife is not working and is a full-time housewife.  He alone has to service the housing loan.  The housing loan repayment every month is $550.  Before he became an informal worker, he had no problem servicing the housing loan.  Because, under the CPF, he has an Ordinary Account and the money in the Ordinary Account was enough for him to service his housing loan.  After two years of not topping his Ordinary Account,  he now has $4,000 in his Ordinary Account.  But his problem is that he has old OA money, but not new OA dollar because he has stopped contributing to his CPF for the last two years.  At the rate things are going, within about eight to 10 months, he will be running out of money in his OA Account.  So in the future, every dollar of $550 monthly repayment would have to come from his own pocket.  This is his first problem.

 

     His second problem is that he has not been contributing Medisave.  If he , his wife and the two children were to fall sick, who is going to fund his Medisave, where is he going to find the money to join the MediShield?  So medical care is the second problem.  His third problem is that today, he is 46 years old.  If he continues working this way until he reaches the retirement age of 62, will he have enough money in his Special Account for his retirement?  He does not think so.  And we do not think so too. So here we have an informal worker doing his best to earn a living, taking home every dollar in the form of cash, but yet running into growing problems compared to those days when he was paying CPF.  He has no new OA, no new Medisave, and in the future, no Special Account for retirement.

 

     Here is another situation. Ms Lee Peck Lian, 63 years old.  She worked almost her

Column: 1952

entire life as a hawker, earning about $600 per month for the last 30 years.  But, fortunately, for her, over the last 30 years, she had faithfully made her Medisave contribution.  Today, her 3-room flat, I believe, is fully paid by her and her husband.  So she does not have to worry about her housing loan.  After working 30 years as a hawker, she decided to stop working as a hawker and, instead, she became a restroom cleaner in a hawker centre some two and a half years ago.  She now earns $700 per month. With overtime of $400 a month, she is making about $1,100 a month.  Because of the years of contribution to Medisave and having completed paying her housing loan, she now has $12,000 in her Medisave Account and Special Account. Over the past 2 1/2 years, because she had been contributing to CPF, she had accumulated another $3,000 in her OA. On top of that, every month, because she is now 63 years old, she pays 7.5% of her salary in the form of CPF and her employer pays 3.5%.  So every month, she adds another $121 into her CPF Account.  So when Workfare announcement came, she was very happy.  Why?  Because on top of $121 she is contributing to her own CPF account today, under the Workfare, she will be getting another $677 in CPF top-up.  She will also get another $274 in cash. Because we have reduced the CPF employee's contribution rate, her take home pay will go up even more.

 

     So here we have two situations - an informal worker without CPF, a formal worker with CPF.  Both are low-wage workers.  But the formal worker, because she took pains to contribute to CPF, as a result, her housing need is addressed, her medical care is addressed, her retirement saving is addressed as well.

 

     Let me put it this way.  The reason why the labour movement fully supports the linkage of Workfare to Medisave and CPF is because we do not look at

Column: 1953

Workfare simply as a means to supplement the income of low-wage workers.  In fact, we believe there should be a much bigger, much more important objective behind the introduction of Workfare.  In other words, through Workfare, we not only want to encourage workers to look for jobs, but more importantly, we want workers to join the Singapore's social safety net.  This social safety net today has got three pillars - housing through OA, medical care through Medisave, retirement through Special Account.  And we believe that, by linking Workfare also to CPF scheme, in fact, we now have a complete system to attract more and more workers to join this social safety net. It is indeed very important that they join this safety net.

 

      (In Mandarin ):  [For vernacular speech, please refer to Appendix A *. ]  Mr Low Thia Khiang said that the Singapore Government is not sincere in helping the informal workers. From the labour movement's point of view, I am not quite sure why he said this. Does it mean that $1 of Workfare in the form of CPF top-up is not real money? Or is it smaller in value? No, it is not. Every dollar is a real dollar, it is genuine and not counterfeit money, and it is not smaller in value. Also, does it mean that low-income workers do not need to have a house for them to live in?  Does it mean that they will not fall sick?  Does it mean that they will not retire forever?  Therefore, I disagree with what Mr Low Thia Khiang said.  He said that the Government lacks sincerity.  However, from the labour's point of view, I say, in fact, our Government has a very good intention.

 

      (In English ):  The purpose of Workfare is to supplement the income of the low-wage workers but, more importantly, to help more and more low-wage workers and informal workers, in particular, to join the social safety net.


*Cols. 2049-2050.

Column: 1954

 

     Let me also say that there is another important purpose of the Workfare which is to find ways to help our workers to keep growing their total wage pie.  The problem faced by low-wage workers is that if their wage pie is small, it does not matter how we cut the wage pie, whether it is today's cash or tomorrow's CPF.  This eventually is still "money no enough". So the way to really solve the low-wage workers' problem is to find ways to enlarge their wage pie and that can only be done if we can find ways to upgrade and enhance their productivity.  That is the reason why the labour movement, over the last two to three years, has been working very closely with the Ministry of Manpower, Workforce Development Authority and Singapore National Employers Federation, through a tripartite effort, to find ways to help our workers to upgrade, redesign and recreate their jobs.

 

     I am happy to say that over the last two to three years, we have been getting some promising results.  Yesterday and today, quite a number of MPs have said that if we feel that cheap sourcing is the cause of the problem and that best sourcing is the solution, then the Government should take the lead.  Here, I am happy to say that, in fact, several Government agencies have taken the lead.  This afternoon, I would just like to mention two examples.  The first example I want to quote, in terms of adopting the concept of best sourcing, is the National Environment Agency (NEA).  NEA manages 27 hawker centres.  For the last two to three years, the NEA had been adopting a performance-based, best-sourcing approach.  For example, there is a company called Horsburgh Engineering.  It is a very responsible company.  The company does not believe in engaging in "red ocean" competition. It believes in competing under the "blue sky" by ensuring that productivity and quality of service are good. Because of the performance based, best sourcing approach adopted by NEA,

Column: 1955

Horsburgh Engineering, even though they are not the lowest cost supplier, has been able to secure 11 out of the 27 hawker centre cleaning contracts.

 

      To clean the 11 hawker centres, Horsburgh employs 400 cleaners.  What is even more exciting is that two to three years ago, 70% of the hawker centre cleaners were illegal foreign workers.  But today, in the case of Horsburgh, 90% of the cleaners are actually Singaporeans.  You may wonder why.  Why is it that 2 1/2 years ago, Singaporeans did not take the job, and today, two to three years later, 90% of them are Singaporeans?

 

      The cynical one will say that, "Oh, now, the workers have no choice.  They are forced to take on these dirty, lousy paying jobs."  But that is not the truth.  The truth is that, over the last two to three years, the NEA has been, firstly, doing industry development by upgrading industry and, secondly, manpower development by upgrading the skills of the workers.  As a result, of the 400 cleaners, 85% of them are more than 40 years old.  The oldest is 70 years old.  They are now earning between $900 and $1,300, depending on how productive they are, how hard they are prepared to work. Compared to two to three years ago, the total wage has gone up by 20% to 30%; in some cases, in fact, almost 50%.

 

     More importantly, every one of them is National Skill Recognition System (NSRS) certified.  So they know the proper way of cleaning. At the same time, I am happy to say that every one of the 400 is entitled to annual leave, insurance, medical coverage and every one of them is on CPF.  This sounds like music to the ears for Mdm Halimah.  This is in fact the case where workers are not exploited under this "blue sky" competition.

 

     Another example is NParks.  NParks has, since 16 months ago, decided to embark on the best sourcing initiatives. 

Column: 1956

NParks manages 52 parks, 233 neighbourhood parks and 21 connectors. They have about 32 maintenance contracts with the industry to maintain all these facilities.  Of the 32 contracts, 17 of them are now under this Best Sourcing initiative.  How does it work?

 

 

 

     In the past, NParks would call for a headcount contract.  For example, NParks says, "Look, I am calling a contract for 10 workers.  Please bid."  When they specify a headcount, what happens?  Companies will bid based on a headcount of 10.  If you were to look at the competitive bids, eventually the one who submits a lower bid would win the tender.  But since the headcount is fixed, what it means is that the dollar available per worker has also come down.

 

     But under Best Sourcing, NParks adopts the concept of performance-based system.  In other words, they do not specify the headcount.  They just specify the performance standards needed, and every week and every month, NParks officers will go around assessing the quality of the work. If the contractor scores 80% or more, they get full payment.  If they score only 75%, they get 88% payment.  If they score less than 59%, they get zero payment.  So, it is truly a performance-based system.  As a result, under this programme, the contractors would make sure that they do the best possible job with as fewer workers as possible.  Why?  Because if you do the best possible job, you get higher payment.  At the same time, with fewer workers, higher productivity per worker, they can reward each worker with a higher salary.  As a result, the workers are better motivated.

 

     Again, I am happy to say that, under this Best Sourcing initiative, the wages of about 195 Singaporean landscaping technicians have gone up from $1,050 per month two years ago to an average

Column: 1957

pay of about $1,200 today, ie, a 15% increase.

 

     Madam, I want to emphasise the point that when we look at Workfare this year, I hope that we do not look at it in the narrow sense of just asking about how many dollars in cash, how much in CPF for each individual worker.  Of course, this is important, but it is also important that we do not lose sight of the bigger picture.  The bigger picture is to help our low-wage workers to grow their wage pie, and that can only be done if we ride on the introduction of Workfare, help more workers to upgrade their skills and jobs and, at the same time, bring them onto the social safety net.  In other words, I would like to repeat what many MPs have said in the last two days.  We are happy that Workfare is a permanent feature of the Singapore social safety net, but we hope that the individual recipients do not become permanent recipients of the Workfare incentives.

 

     Let me now go on to touch on the issue of the middle-income workers.  A few fellow parliamentary colleagues mentioned that many of the middle-income workers feel that they have not been as well looked after in this particular Budget as compared to, say, the low-wage and other categories of workers.

 

     I want to share a labour movement perspective.  When I first joined the labour movement in 1996, I visited Japan.  There, I met with a union leader and I asked her:  "In Japan, what is your main concern?"  She said that, in Japan, they believe that if the workers were to chase after money, money will run away from the workers.  But if the workers chase after jobs, money will run to the workers.  She went on to say that, "Better still, if we can get workers to chase after jobs and jobs chase after workers, then all will be well because, if the labour market is

Column: 1958

tight, wages will go up."  I am happy to say that, in fact, this is what is happening in Singapore.  It is something that I hope more of us will pay attention to.

 

      In a recent report released by the Department of Statistics on key household income trends, it is very interesting if we look at the overall average household monthly income from work per capita, ie, taking the average income earned per month from every household divided by the number of persons per family.  So it is the dollar income per month per person from work.  In 2002, on the whole, throughout Singapore, the average income from work per capita per household dropped by 2.1% from the year 2001.  But last year, it went up by 5.7%.  Why is it so?  Because 2006 was a good year.  The economy grew strongly, companies and industries were profitable, bonuses went up and, as a result, average income per capita went up by 5.7%.  In fact, everybody benefited from this rise in average household income per capita.

 

     Take, for example, the bottom 30th percentile.  The increase in per capita household income went up by 5.2% to 6.6%.  So it is not an insignificant increase.  The middle-income group, ie, the 40th to 50th percentile, went up by 4.2%-4.6%, and the top-income obviously is the happiest group because it went up by 8%.  In other words, creating jobs and growth is the best Workfare for the middle-income workers because, with a tight labour market and profitable industries, there would be more to share for everyone.  The question is, will we be able to continue to create high growth, strong job growth in 2007, just like in 2006?  The answer is that it may be yes, it may be no.  May be yes, because we have all the right strategies in place; may be no, if we are not able to meet the global competition.

 

     The good news is this.  In the world out there, there are still many good

Column: 1959

investments and good jobs for us to chase after.  But the bad news is that more and more countries and economies are going after these good investments and jobs.  Just three days ago, on Monday, on the front page of the Straits Times was a report headlined "India going all out to woo wafer fab plants".  Why is India all of a sudden interested in competing for wafer fabrication plants?  Because if you look at wafer fabrication plants, firstly, it is capital-intensive.  Every wafer fabrication plant will cost about US$1 billion to US$2 billion to build.  Secondly, it is technology-intensive.  Thirdly, it is manpower-intensive.  Every wafer fabrication plant will create about 1,000 jobs.  So, for such investments, there is high-tech, high capital and high manpower demand as well as good paying jobs.  Obviously, these are good investments that many countries would want to compete for.  So the bad news is that more and more people are competing for all these good investments.

 

     Where does that leave Singapore?  On the whole, I would say that the outlook is still positive. Why?  Because it is very difficult to satisfy the demand of these wafer fabrication plant investors.  For example, wafer fabrication is water-intensive.  Every plant will consume about half a million to one million gallons of water every day.  More importantly, the water must be very pure because they are dealing with integrated circuits.  They also need a big piece of land because you cannot stack wafer fabs one on top of another and make them high-rise factories.  As I mentioned, they need a lot of manpower, about 1,000.  And not just any manpower, but well-trained, skilled and professional manpower.  On top of that, all these integrated circuits (ICs) do not take ship; they go by air.  So you must have good air cargo logistics services. In fact, it is not easy to attract this kind of investment.  But precisely because it is so difficult to compete for wafer fabrication investments, it gives us a better chance

Column: 1960

of succeeding.  Why?  Because the more difficult it is, the more we can run ahead of the competition.

 

     Take water, for example.  We have not much water.  But PUB came up with NEWater.  As a result, today, almost every wafer fabrication plant in Singapore no longer uses PUB water.  They have all switched to NEWater.  It is cleaner and cheaper.  In terms of land, we have limited land, but URA did a rezoning and, over the last 10 years, we created not one, two, three but four wafer fab parks, from Woodlands, Tampines and Pasir Ris to Ang Mo Kio.  In terms of manpower, do we have enough manpower?  Over 10 years of development, we have attracted about 14 to 15 wafer fabrication plants.  Today, there is a cluster in Singapore.

 

     The total employment is 15,000 people working in the wafer fab plants.  And the interesting thing is that if you look at the operator's level, in fact, about two-thirds of them are foreign workers.  But at the PMET level, 80% are Singaporeans and PRs.  In other words, because we are smart and receptive enough to bring the foreign workers and foreign talents from around the world, as a result, not only are we able to create an industry cluster and 15,000 good-paying jobs, most of the good-paying jobs go to Singaporeans.

 

     Madam, the fact that we have succeeded in creating the wafer fabrication cluster, notwithstanding all the limitations we face in the form of water, land, etc, has given us a lot of confidence that if we continue to apply our minds, upgrade our capabilities, expand our capacities, invest in the future, there is no reason why we cannot continue to succeed in this difficult world of globalisation.  Yes, globalisation is challenging and will result in the same implications for all economies. But we all know that globalisation will lead to unequal outcome.  Those that are able to respond to globalisation will become

Column: 1961

winners and those that are not able to respond to globalisation will turn out to be the losers.  And we have been a winner in the world of globalisation all these years and we must continue to enlarge the pie, create more jobs, grow our economy, so that there will be the best outcome for all levels of workers.

 

     Last but not least, this Budget is also about investing in our future.  Earlier, our parliamentary colleague, Ms Lee Bee Wah, said that we should not leave it to chance or chuan dao qiao tou zi ran zhi.  I agree with her fully.  Singapore of today did not happen by chance.  We created the Singapore of today, and we will continue to create the Singapore of tomorrow.  We must all recognise that the "blue-ocean economy" of yesterday has become the "blue-sky economy" of today.  The "ho tan" will become "giam tan" because of globalisation.  Likewise, the "blue-sky economy" of today will end up to be the "red-ocean economy" of tomorrow, and the "giam tan" will become the "bo tan" or "pai tan" because of globalisation.

 

     Do we have a choice?  Can we run away from globalisation?  There is no way.  China started off with manufacturing.  They are now moving into services.  India started off with services but is now moving into manufacturing. So when all these competitors start to come in to cover all areas, the only way for us to do is to keep creating new space for ourselves in the blue ocean.  Of course, if we are big and fast, that is ideal.  America is quite close to that, ie, big economy, very dynamic, innovative, so it is a good example of big and fast.  But being small and slow is certainly a deadly combination.  So, for Singapore, we cannot try to be big.  Even if we go to a 6.5 million population, it is still small.  So we cannot be big.  But we must make sure that we never end up being slow.  Because if we are small and slow, that

Column: 1962

would be the end of Singapore.  If we look at Singapore today, we are small but we are fast.  And precisely because we are small and fast, as a result, in the latest report published in September last year by the World Economic Forum, Singapore is today one of the top five most competitive economies in the world, together with Switzerland, Finland, Sweden and Denmark.  What are the common features of these top five most competitive economies of the world?  Interestingly, they are all small and fast.  And this is the reason why we must continue to remain small and fast so that we can continue to grow, prosper and create a better future for all.

 

     Sir, please allow me to conclude in Mandarin.

Column: 1962

The Government has to make decisions and sometimes, they are difficult decisions in 

Column: 1964

response to whatever challenges we face, especially in the face of rapid globalisation.  And also in response to her 60-year-old man's comment about "Love people and do not love things", let me share with her that nowhere else in the world can you get a Budget which exudes love and compassion in abundance as this one.

 

   Globalisation is here to stay and we will embrace it as a nation hand-in-hand and adapt to the new reality.  But it comes with some  challenges.  Whereas it is easy for some of us to identify with globalisation and its opportunities, how about the average man-in-the-street, the lower 20% of society and those who live from day-to-day and the elderly?  Their question would be:  what is in it for us?  What does globalisation mean to them?  They have to understand the effects of globalisation.  It will affect their employability and, of course, their job security.  In their current jobs, it is not just comparing themselves to the guy who sits at the next counter.  It now boils down to comparing himself to the average worker in China, India or Russia.  He has to realise the competition is now that great. 

 

   To adapt, he has to change his mindset, be more outward-looking and get a wider perspective, change some of his traditional and conventional views, even if he does not have to travel out of Singapore.  Parents and the elderly will need to realise the importance of investment in the next generation because their children are the ones who are going to be immersed in this new world order.  For example, investing in their sound educational grounding now will prepare them just for this.  For indeed, education is the key to handling and adapting to globalisation changes all over the world. They must be encouraged to grab the opportunities.  I therefore applaud the Post-Secondary Education Assistance fund.  One example I would like to highlight is the Malay/Muslim community

Column: 1965

efforts to standardise the madrasah education.  From next year, the madrasah primary schools will be taking the same national PSLE examinations as every other Primary Six child.

 

   The lower-income, the unskilled and the elderly workers must become more proactive and vigilant. The Workfare Income Supplement scheme is a major policy change to help them.  The introduction of Workfare as a permanent fourth pillar is a plus point for them.  But they must identify and realise why they need training and retraining, skills acquisition and lifelong learning, or they stand the chance of becoming redundant especially in the age of high technology and mechanisation.  Job security and empowerment will help them move towards being able to fend for themselves.  Therefore, we must all play a role in helping them in the spirit of brotherhood. Employers and the unions must continue to bridge the knowledge of the Skills Development Fund or the Lifelong Learning Endowment Fund to them because they can now apply directly.  Members of Parliament, grassroots leaders and even the media too can play a role by creating and enhancing awareness.

 

    I move on now to healthcare.  With Singapore having the lowest infant mortality rate in the world and as we rank third in the world in terms of life expectancy, which is now 81.7 years, people are living longer. The bulk of our healthcare expenditure will be attributed to the elderly as they are high consumers of healthcare anywhere in the world.  To tackle this problem, we must, either, firstly, free market regulation systems by using drug-related groups (DRGs) and resource-based relative value scales, or secondly, evaluate the needs and demands of our population and structure our healthcare system and financing

Column: 1966

accordingly.  We already are doing both, but we need more to plan for the elderly explosion we are going to face. The population over 60 years of age is going to increase from 6.8% currently to 15.7% in 2020 and 56.7% by 2050.  With ageing comes along dementia-related illnesses. This year alone, there are about 23,000 elderly who are diagnosed with dementia.  By 2020, the number will rise to 54,000 and by 2050, we are going to hit 188,000 people with dementia. 

 

    A report commissioned by the Alzheimer's Disease International suggests dementia-related illnesses may soon overtake heart disease and cancer as the biggest health threat in the Asia Pacific region. We need to cope with these projected numbers.  We need to conduct local studies and analysis on the direct and indirect cost of managing the elderly with dementia, Alzheimer's diseases, and so on.  And we need to fine-tune the ways to finance and organise care over the coming years. 

 

    If an average 60-year-old does not have enough money in his or her Medisave and healthcare insurance, what will be the options?  In this context, I am glad to hear of the $200 million top-up of the Medifund and the upcoming enhancement to the Eldershield scheme. The new scheme with CPF and Medisave opportunities for the informal workers and the contract workers is indeed a plus point in this year's Budget as well.  But what will be the implications to our 3M system?  What will be the cost to the elderly patients and to Singapore for each additional life year?  We need to take into account that medical technology will add cost for additional life year.  The Ministry of Health may also want to consider doing some quality of life measurements with a focus on its future trends, looking at health priorities within an integrated framework for elderly care. We will be needing more hospitals, nursing homes and step-down care beds in the coming

Column: 1967

years.  In the United Kingdom, guidelines for service according to the Royal College of Physicians and also the Royal College of Psychiatrists states that for an elderly population of 30,000, there must be 45 acute beds, 75 day hospital places and 75 continuing care beds, which is the equivalent of our step-down care beds.

 

    It is time for us to project our local numbers for the coming years.  Singaporeans must plan for their golden years from now, from our diets to lifestyle and the decisions that we make.  Education on self-management and empowerment for the elderly can start from mid-life.  A good prototype I would like to share is the Young at Heart Community College or the YAH Community College which is pioneered by the Marine Parade Family Service Centre.  Here, we have middle-aged as well as the older generation being enrolled in courses as though they are going to universities which are useful in their day-to-day living.  Several batches have now graduated and they have only positive things to say about the programme.  Perhaps, more funding can be channelled into this meaningful programme from MCYS and also NCSS.

 

    Mdm Deputy Speaker, in the United States, President George Bush has recently trimmed his healthcare expenditure to seek a more balanced budget. There is going to be a US$70 million cut from Medicare and Medicaid over the next five years.  The democratic law-makers are calling this, and I quote, "Pulling the lifeline on the poor".   We must never get to that stage.  In Singapore, our healthcare financing model ensures fiscal sustainability and affordability by all, while some may need a little bit more help than others, with shared responsibility between individual and society.

 

    With the formalisation of SingaporeMedicine, more foreigners will be seeking medical care here. The numbers are projected to rise to one million by the year

Column: 1968

2012. We must prepare by planning now with expansion of services, increase manpower of the various appropriate disciplines in the right proportions, increase bed capacity and outpatient specialist clinic slots. We are going to have to meet the increased demands of healthcare of these foreign medical tourist patients or our own patients of the increasing number of elderly with multiple problems that we are going to face and also the increased number of patients to be generated from our call to foreign talent to come and settle in Singapore. The time to start preparing is indeed now and I certainly see changes announced in this Budget, gearing us slowly but surely in this direction.

 

    In research and development, the research community is delighted with the projected increment of the R&D budget up to 3% of the GDP annually by 2010.  This also comes with another $500 million for the National Research Fund. This is seen as an investment for Singapore's future, planning for growth in this area which comes along with job creation, technology enhancement and also intellectual property development.  I hope to see some of these monies channelled into research related to the elderly, dementia, psychogeriatrics and also psychological health.  These are often called the softer sciences and they have not been given too much emphasis so far, but we would like to see that change. 

 

    Philanthropy refers to the desire to help mankind while volunteerism is the offering of services based on one's own free will.  The call by the Second Minister for Finance in his Budget speech for Singapore to become a Philanthropy Hub is indeed a very fresh perspective, very different from the usual call to become a financial hub, a medical hub or a trading hub.  We can be whatever we set our minds towards and strive for.  His call is on target as Singapore has great potential to become the volunteer capital of Asia. 

Column: 1969

Our position is conducive. We are at the crossroads of Asia, Southeast Asia.  Our reputation is well-known in Singapore, it is synonymous with trustworthiness, action and accountability. The new 80:20 rule which we are doing away with is indeed very attractive as well, and that Asia is a disaster-prone zone may be an impetus for this.  Philanthropy on a smaller scale must be promoted through the enhancement of the spirit of volunteerism amongst our people.  Volunteerism promotes community bonding as well in the development of a gentle and gracious society.  It will strengthen the sense of belonging - the Singapore heartbeat.  The moral test of any society is how we treat our weakest, our elderly, our underprivileged or disabled, our needy and our sick.  This Budget represents the heartware for us to do all these.  But we, the people, need to provide the software. Our national volunteerism rate is at 15.2% at the last NVPC survey of 2004.  More companies and corporations will need to recognise and participate in volunteer and philanthropic activities.  Corporate volunteerism must expand.  Corporations' performance is now being judged to the triple bottom line of economic, environmental and also the social contribution.  Companies promoting volunteerism and also philanthropy must be given some kind of recognition.  The recognition and allocation of volunteer leave need to be formalised as well and taken more seriously.  Recognition and using of role models must be stepped up.  We must become a more gracious society and continue to build on our heartware.  Only in this way can we achieve our civil society with active citizenship through volunteerism and philanthropy, and I am sure our happiness index will improve as well and route towards becoming a top level first-world nation.

 

     Mdm Deputy Speaker, with all these, we will grow the Singapore pie.  Mr Lim

Column: 1970

Swee Say has confirmed that the pie is not going to grow too large.  Well, we will not be able to sub-divide it into too many minute sub-segments, as it would not satisfy our appetite.  Perhaps the day will come when we can actually twin the pie and even triplicate the pie, and perhaps we can have different flavoured filling as well to choose from.

 

 

 

 

6.48 pm

 

     Mr Sam Tan Chin Siong (Tanjong Pagar): Mdm Deputy Speaker, I would like to speak in Mandarin first and in English later.

 

     (In Mandarin):  [For vernacular speech, please refer to Appendix A *.]  Mr Speaker, Sir, this Budget is generally well received at all levels of the society. But there is an old saying, "Even the wise are not always free from error." Some of the MPs have pointed out that the Budget has its inadequacy. However, one point to take note is that the comments are pertaining to the policy details. As for the overall Budget, it is worthy of praise. Even the Member for Hougang, Mr Low Thia Khiang, makes positive appraisal of this

Column: 1971

Budget. He feels that the Government need not increase GST and it will still be able to afford a series of assistance schemes and subsidy allowances. As my fellow colleagues have already refuted his views, I will not elaborate further on this.

However, there are some people who are confused by the Budget. For instance, they do not know how much cash will be given by the Government, the amount of subsidy given to their CPF account, the criteria to be entitled for these benefits, etc.  This is because the Budget can be complicated for those who are lowly educated and illiterate.


     If we recall, last year, when the Government distributed the Progress Package to the people, as many as 19,000 people did not apply for it by June 2006. It was through subsequent house-to-house visits conducted by the grassroots leaders that people understand more about the Progress Package. Eventually, about 20% of the people in this group managed to receive their Progress Package. It is a pity that many more people were not able to benefit from this package. Budget 2007 provides more assistance schemes, each with varying amounts. For those who are not well educated, it may be difficult for them to successfully obtain these schemes.


     Therefore, I would like to urge the Government to take into consideration the previous experience, so as to simplify the administrative process. At the same time, we should educate the people through various channels about the application procedures, as well as the deadline for application. Also, the grassroots organisations and the People's Association

Column: 1972

could assist those who are not clear about the application process. This will, no doubt, be a tedious process, but it will ensure that the lower income and the elderly group will benefit from the Budget.


     In this regard, I would like to propose that the Government put in place some measures to prevent businessmen and hawkers from making use of this opportunity to jack up the prices of their goods. This will weaken the intended benefits of the GST offset package. In the past, I understand that the Government had set up a committee to look into this matter. But, according to past experiences, the grassroots leaders appointed by the committee had to carry out mediation and they advised businessmen and hawkers against carrying out unlawful practices.  The mediator did not have the power to enforce the laws and, as such, it did not have much binding effect on the businessmen. This is like the Chinese saying, "a paper tiger" meaning it is ineffective.


     The above views and comments may not have direct impact or relationship on the Budget-related assistance packages, but they are the aspirations and voices as well as the hopes of the people. Hence, I do hope that the Government can pay closer attention to the voices of these people, so that we can achieve complete success for this Budget.


     Madam, I would like to continue my speech in English.

 

     (In English):

 

Watershed

 

     Many people have called this Budget a watershed.  From my memory, many Budgets have been called "watersheds" in the past. For me, this Budget is not special just because we spend money on the poor - it is of no great difficulty to know that we should help the poor, and

Column: 1973

our Government has always done so.   This is also not the first time that the Government's Budget is pro-business or pro-worker.  So, this Budget is again not special in this sense.  But, for me, this Budget is very special because it is a return to the socialist roots of the People's Action Party.

 

     Mdm Deputy Speaker, we have been called by many people as pragmatists, as if we have neither a brain nor a heart, but merely a super efficient computer or calculator to churn out the maximum output from a limited input.  However, this Budget shows that we are more than a computer or a calculator.  In this Budget, there is compassion beyond logic, there is warm empathy beyond cool rationality.  This Budget also shows that our Government has maintained the founding leaders' commitment towards equality in opportunities and fairness in the distribution of goods.

 

     It also shows that the idea of equity and equality needs to be clearly distinguished.  We do not give everyone the same amount of help, because we are not all created equally.  Some need more help than others.  This is the context in which the Workfare bonus, CPF increase, GST offset package and other incentives and tax measures ought to be seen.

 

A new socialism

 

     Madam, with this Budget, the Government has created a permanent structure in giving people money creatively in the name of Workfare.  In the past, the Government has given out money to Singaporeans mainly under crisis conditions, such as during the SARS period, and we all know that the help packages will stop once life is back to normal.

 

    Occasionally, the Government also gives out bonuses, such as New

Column: 1974

Singapore Shares, when there are budget surpluses.  Now, the Government has made Workfare a permanent feature of its policy.   Workfare is not a simple needs-based welfare system where "from each his needs" is the principle, like the traditional socialism.  We have, I think, adopted a kind of modern socialism where state subsidies are accompanied by a preservation of the work ethic.  In other words, it is work-driven and not needs-based.  To me, a permanent work-driven Workfare scheme is a sound principle and a much superior approach to the permanent needs-based social welfare scheme.  Even the hon. Member for Hougang has conceded this and supported the Workfare programme although his party has been advocating permanent needs-based social assistance.

 

     Workfare does not erode the workers' motivation to work, and yet helps those whose work does not yield as much pay as they need.  This is a unique and special formula which can make our society more caring without losing our competitive spirit.

 

New social contract

 

     Mdm Deputy Speaker, that is on a philosophical level.  On a human relationship level, we need to establish a new relationship with Singaporeans.  I read some news reports on people's reactions to the Budget and could not help but had a feeling that some people are, perhaps unconsciously, beginning to take the various help packages as their rights.

 

     For example, I read an article in a Chinese newspaper of a man whose family received almost $5,000 from the various help packages under the new Budget.  His reaction to these goodies?  He said that the Budget is only "okay" - hai ke yi -  and more needs to be done.  He further commented that his family has a few children and therefore should get more money than his friend who is a

Column: 1975

single.  From his perspective, these feelings are understandable, but that in itself is also a manifestation of "never enough" attitude.  He probably forgot that his school-going children would get other incentives while his single friend would not.

 

    We have to guard against breeding an over-dependence on the Government which may inadvertently create a Singapore populated by citizens who think of themselves as "never satisfied" customers. 

 

Coming out of Plato's cave

 

     Mdm Deputy Speaker, I have said earlier that this Budget has broken new barriers but is also a return to our political roots.  In a way, it is an easy decision because the social and economic problems addressed in this Budget are real and immediate.

 

     I want to suggest another area which is quite visibly missed out in this Budget, but one that has to be done - a far more intractable area, because the problems are long term and, for now, intangible.  I am talking about the environment - an issue which quite a few Members of the House had mentioned before me.  I am happy for this, because it means that more of us are conscious of this urgent need.  Today, I would like to add my voice to this cause.

 

     As I speak now, we are standing, or sitting, if you prefer, on the tip of a fast-melting iceberg.  The global consumption of energy, the disregard of the rapid rates of deforestation, the contamination of water, all these are unsustainable, and yet there is a relentless eating up of these resources in many parts of the world.  We, the people of today, are making the decisions for the people of tomorrow.  It is always hard to make decisions that will be popular only 50 years from today, when it is easier to make decisions that will win the next election.

 

    

Column: 1976

        But, in Singapore, we have taken hard and unpopular decisions before.  For example, we have looked towards the long term, and helped to break the backs of anti-business unions in Singapore in the 1960s.  After that, unions and business have worked together to solve problems for the long term.  It was not something that made us immediately popular then, but it was good for the long haul.

 

     Similarly, we resettled people from their homes and farms into high-rise HDB flats from 1960s through to the 1980s.  It was a very difficult and unpopular move, but we did it.

 

     We need to build on the trust that we have established over the past four decades and ask the people to change their way of living.  We all need to realise that simple but significant changes need to be made to our lifestyles if we are to conserve the fragile balance of our environment.

 

    As policy makers, there are five simple things which I think the Government can do:

 

     (i)  Make sure that recycling bins and efforts are widespread and in every ward;

 

     (ii)  Give tax rebates for companies which are environmentally friendly;

 

     (iii)  Think twice or three times before cutting down old and mature trees;

 

     (iv)  Be less aggressive in acquisition efforts and tearing down old but still functional buildings, eg, the old National Library

 

 

was torn down and replaced by a tunnel; and

 

     (v) Participate more actively in global efforts to save the environment.  Our Ambassador-at-large Prof. Tommy Koh's efforts on this front have been exemplary. 

Column: 1977

He has chaired the Earth Summit and the Law of the Sea.  Mdm Deputy Speaker, we should give Prof. Koh a larger role and leverage on Singapore's role as an impartial and responsible world player on environmental issues.  We can be the champion for environment conservation.

 

     I would like to share a little story that has created a big impression on me.  There was once a man  who lived in a cave with other men.  They had no idea of the world outside and were content to live within the stone walls, scrawling pictures with coal and watching the fire burn.  One day, one man, wiser, braver, more curious than the rest, ventured outside.  He saw what it was - the real world.  He went back into the cave and got his fellow men.  He told them to do the hard things that they needed to do, so that all could progress from the cave into a new reality.  This is not a fairy tale from Hans Christian Anderson which I have mentioned in my maiden speech.  Quite the reverse.  It is from Greek philosopher Plato's Republic, which was written about 2,300 years ago.  Mdm Deputy Speaker, we the people in this House are collectively that man who has wandered out from that cave.  We are the ones who have the ability and capability to show and lead the rest of the men. 

 

     We know the truth and the severe cost about climate change, we know the many drastic measures we have to take, if our grandchildren are to continue to have a beautiful world to grow up in. We have a choice - either to ignore these facts or bring them up to our fellowmen.  For me, this is Hobson's choice.  We have emerged from the cave and we need to go back to tell our fellow men what we have seen.  Not because we are any smarter, not because we have better answers, but because we have promised to be their leaders and it is our duty to lead them out of the cave and into a new and better life.

 

Column: 1978

     On this note, Mdm Deputy Speaker, I support the Budget.

Column: 1979

instance, what should we do? In fact, that has been our headache for many years and, therefore, I feel that this is the most resolute as well as the most generous Budget.


     Under the new leadership of our Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong, he has decided to put in place a series of measures to help the poor and needy, so as to narrow the income gap.  If you had read the Lianhe Zaobao two days ago, there was an article about the United States. It is a country that many people are dreaming of and a lot of people are eager to go there.  They have done well and will continue to be a country that people look forward to go to. However, in the US, they are facing the problem of widening income gap for many years.      Just now, Dr Fatimah said that the US is going to further decrease its health budget.  Therefore, I must say that we are in a very fortunate era.  I can say that this is a golden era for Singapore because we have quite a substantial sum of reserves, returns from overseas investments, and good economic progress. This is the best time for us to revise our tax regime and to help the lower-income group.  This is the most appropriate time now. After hearing from our leaders and reading a lot of reports, under this highly competitive environment and wave of globalisation, what should we do to attract investments?  The solution is to reduce our

Column: 1980

tax rates in order to attract foreign investments.  I believe Hong Kong, in their recent budget debate, may also reduce their tax rates. So what should we do as a small country? We are not able to further increase direct tax, we can only lower it.  As such, our corporate income tax will be lowered by two percentage points in order to attract more foreign investments.  Even personal income tax can hardly be raised.


     Some MPs even suggest that if we want to attract foreign talent, we should reduce the personal income tax rates.  Under such circumstances, I feel that a more extensive tax regime whereby everyone can share some responsibility is a better tax system. However, we do face some challenges when we increase the GST, particularly in the area of helping the poor to cope with this pressure.  In this regard, I am very glad to know that our Second Minister for Finance has announced a very generous GST offset package. It is able to offset the negative effects of GST for more than 10 years.  Hence, I feel that this Budget is really very generous. It is so generous that it makes me wonder if there are any additional strings attached, or if it is subject to any conditions.


     The NTUC Secretary-General has earlier highlighted that Workfare is a very good scheme to help the low-income workers.  However, I would suggest using a two-pronged approach: to raise their level of technical ability, so as to help them earn higher wages.  Under the ComCare scheme, the Government has recently been promoting the work support plan and it has been doing well.  It means that when we try to match a job for the unemployed, we also advise them to go for training. After the training, more than 50% of the workers get a new job and their pay has increased by an average of more than $300. I think that is a very encouraging situation.  Therefore, our

Column: 1981

challenge is to design a training programme that is linked up with the Workfare scheme. This will apply to all existing workers as well as elderly workers. As we know, we are facing an increasing life expectancy, while technology, knowledge and product life cycles have been shortening.


     I have a friend who works in a Sony factory and he designs electronic products. He said that, for the mobile phone design, there will be a new product every three months.  I asked him what the latest product is now. Maybe even I am not able to catch up with the new technology. This will mean that for every three months or six months, we have to learn how to use a new product.  So time is not going to wait for us.
