     In my younger days, after my graduation, I attended a booking-keeping course at the Adult Education Board during the weekend, and so I have some accounting experience. I feel that every one should recognise the fact that the knowledge they receive in school, polytechnic or university, has a limited knowledge value lifespan, and this

Column: 1982

lifespan is getting shorter now - it is only five years. Similarly, it is just like our doctors.  After a few years, they have to go for re-examination.  We must think of some ways to enhance the technical skills of our people.  However, this will require the tripartite cooperation and we can only achieve this objective through joint efforts by all parties. In this regard, we have various measures in place. For instance, NTUC offers different schemes, and WDA has many such schemes as well. But the question is really whether we have personally done anything.  I think what we should do is to find ways and means to encourage our people. In some countries, there are some cases whereby people are not aware, they do not want to ask or they do not want to find out. Therefore, the people must be more pro-active in this aspect and they must take the initiative to find out about the Government policies. The people need to understand the schemes that are made available to them. We should not behave "do nothing and die". Of course, we should not be "忧天忧人" [you ren you tian ], meaning too worrisome. Also, we should not put the blame on others for our failure or our hardships.


      The Government can only do this much by providing us with basic facilities, education and training opportunities and opening up pathways for us. Eventually, it is our responsibility to ask and find out, and if you think that the plan is too complicated, you do not have to learn about the details. You can make your enquiries, ask your MP during the meet-the-people session, check out at the Community Clubs or the Family Service Centres, or maybe even at the market place where there are grassroots members who can provide you with some information.  Therefore, it is impossible for any one to say that they are not aware. I hope that every one of us could pay more attention to the Budget package, and

Column: 1983

understand how it will affect us. As such, I describe this package and WIS as tools that will help us to take off. Before the plane takes off, we will have to tighten our safety belt and not safety net, because when we refer to safety net it means giving social welfare to the unemployed, but the safety belt means that all of us will take off together. You will have to be on board the plane to have the safety belt and, therefore, we must prepare ourselves and get ready for the take-off.


     Recently, I asked my friend for comments regarding the Budget announcement and was told "无为不治" [wu wei bu zhi] - meaning the Government should operate on a policy of non-interference. My friend said that the Government has done too much. "无为" [wu wei] is a Taoist saying - meaning non-interference. But, in this instance, our PAP Government will not agree to "无为" [wu wei] - not doing anything, because we are "有为" [you wei ]. Most importantly, I have heard discussions on the issue of Medisave contributions: how we can encourage informal workers to open a CPF account so that it will enable them to contribute one-third to Medisave Fund, while the Government will top-up the remaining two-thirds. I believe that the Minister for Health, Mr Khaw Boon Wan, is appearing in local papers almost every day, urging us to open a Medisave account for our families, our spouses and our children. And now, the Second Minister for Finance also urges us to make use of this opportunity to make contributions to CPF as well as open an account.


     Earlier on, our NTUC Secretary-General also quoted a few examples on the benefits of having a CPF account. Therefore, I believe that Singaporeans no longer can claim that they have not heard anything or know anything. I hope that all of us will do our part. It is for our own interest because one day we will fall sick

Column: 1984

or we will retire and it is thus necessary for us to open a CPF account, contribute over $20 every month and the Government will subsidise a portion for us. If the effort is still not enough, we may even have to launch some campaigns among the communities to raise the awareness of our residents. But if you still refuse to listen after much advice, then the description of "坐以待毙" [zuo yi dai bi ] - meaning “do nothing and die” will inevitably happen to some of us.


     During conversations with friends, we discuss about the future policies in Singapore, and how we can achieve the Prime Minister’s vision to transform Singapore into a highly efficient and vibrant global city.  Minister Mentor has envisaged that Singapore will become a world-class city. Personally, I think that we have a high level of efficiency.  As for harmony, my Ministry is still working hard and the Minister will be speaking on this. Sometimes, we must also think about the perception of a so-called Charming Singapore.  Many of my friends gave their feedback on a "Charming Singapore" and they said that over the past few years, Minister Mah Bow Tan has put in great efforts and we must acknowledge that we have made many changes in the appearance of our city.  Our roads are much more beautiful and we have more greenery.  A few persons have commented that during the day time when we take a drive from Changi Airport to the city, the scenery on either side is very attractive.  The water is clear and clean, the trees and flowers are green and scenic. But at night, when we drive along the same highway, travelling along East Coast Parkway, it is rather pitch-dark. Therefore, to become more charming, some people suggest that we need to have better designs for our lighting and lamp lights. Of course, we do not want to be like some countries where they have lightings in disorganised confusion. Rather, we should have more sophisticated, graceful and artistic designs. We may need to

Column: 1985

engage the French designers to work on it so as to make the lightings more romantic.  I am not sure if this will have any positive impact on our population but we may be able to attract more tourists.


     On another point, the Second Minister has mentioned earlier that for us to build a successful nation, we need to have supporting infrastructure. Some friends and grassroots organisations have reminded us of the need for a full-scale development in our creative spirit and humanities, so that when people come to Singapore, in terms of our hardware, they will feel that it is a fresh and beautiful place and, at the same time, they will also be impressed by our software. In this regard, we have earlier mentioned a few areas of development, such as human resource, technical and cultural developments. Most importantly, we have to develop our spiritual civilisation in areas such as culture, television, radio broadcasting, language, communication skills, our appearance and attire. So we must be consistent in our inner thoughts and outward behaviour.  This means that we must also attain inner qualities of virtue. So whether we have achieved a world-class standard is another question.

 

     Recently, during the World Bank conference, it was mentioned that we would like to achieve our goal of four million smiles.  Have we consistently been encouraging our people to meet others with a smiling face? If we want to develop the IRs and to enhance our city as a cultural city and to attract top talents from overseas, it is important to develop this aspect. The development of these software qualities can become an enterprise itself.  If we link this up with the concept of an “enterprise”, perhaps it can be more easily understood by our Finance Minister. In other words, the enterprise here is referring to an industry that specialises in grooming and packaging, so

Column: 1986

as to sell certain abilities. We should not say that the Filipino ladies have the sweetest smile or the Shanghainese women are the sweetest.  In our context, this will also apply to the men, not only the women in Singapore. I hope that we will cultivate our students and Singaporeans to greet people with a flattering smile, and to carry oneself with ease and confidence. I say that this can also become an industry.


     Another area will be the food and beverage industry, which is also considered as software.   Recently, some chefs said that they want to go for overseas international competitions but there is a lack of sponsorship.  Under our software development, we hope to encourage more celebrity chefs to participate in overseas international competitions, so that when they come back, they can also improve the quality of our food.  I remember Minister Lim has earlier talked about a book that says that if you have to visit one thousand places in this lifetime, you should come to Singapore for the food. "吃在新加坡" [Chi Zai Xin Jia Po]. Come for the food in Singapore. The Chinese saying goes, "衣食住行, 人以食为天" [Yi Shi Zhu Xing Ren Yi Shi Wei Tian ].  Among the basic necessities of life, food is termed the most important.  This is our advantage in Singapore - good food.  And I do believe our chefs are good at fusion cooking techniques, combining eastern and western styles. For these small industries, we should continue to encourage and reward them.


     As for the performing arts, I believe that Mr Baey can put in extra efforts to promote our performing arts industry such as MediaCorp, our movies and computer animation.  It seems that we are lagging behind Korea in these aspects.  But I do not believe that we lack talents.  We have many talented people, but usually they have to be packaged and marketed overseas.  A good example is Stephanie

Column: 1987

Sun. She is a good singer but she has to go to Taiwan for packaging, before she became famous and returned home.


     Earlier on, my fellow MP also asked us to consider whether or not to proceed with a worldwide exhibition on toilets.  Our reply to the organiser was that the event has to be hosted successfully overseas before it is held here in Singapore. There is feedback that we should search and unearth talents in all areas by giving them scholarships to assist them with re-packaging as well as to help them upgrade their skills. These are the so-called software industry.


     Another industry that I am more familiar with is education. MOE encourages the development of Singapore into an educational hub, with regard to professional training, primary, secondary and university education.  We have spent more than 20 years to develop our early childhood education. And our nursery and kindergartens have plenty of experiences in the operations. But now, we are still looking forward to Australia and US as our learning model. Should we not encourage our people, schools and institutions that are experienced in this area to develop Singapore into an early childhood education hub, as well as a training hub for teachers in early childhood profession? I do believe that we have a role to play in the international arena. This will also be part of our software development, and it is also an industry.


     Finally, I want to discuss about "Wow, Charming Singapore."  I have briefly mentioned earlier that, to achieve this, one needs to look charming and the place must look beautiful too.  Currently, in terms of development of our hardware, we have emphasised mainly on Marina South, Clarke Quay and Boat Quay.  But if we are using the 6.5 million population as a standard gauge for design, we must

Column: 1988

consider more areas for hardware development.  As Dr Fatimah has mentioned earlier, on the hardware development of hospitals, I strongly agree with Minister Khaw Boon Wan. In our effort to develop world-class hospitals, who should be the one leading this role?  Should private hospitals be the key driver?  Or should it be the Government hospitals?  Or should Government hospitals continue to ensure that basic healthcare is provided for its people at an affordable level?  Should this concept be applied to other facilities, for example, our transport system and other hardware facilities, etc?


     Take, for instance, our transport system.  If we are looking at achieving the target of 6.5 million population, should we look at other alternatives? Being an island surrounded by water, maybe one way is to explore having ferry service.  In view of our greying population, apart from the bustling and busy areas, should we consider having a lower-tier transport system in our HDB heartland?  All these are just some ideas, but how can we make them reasonable and provide alternative choices for our people, so that we make them feel that it is affordable?  Maybe in some areas, we need to have two different rulings, so as to reach a world-class city standard. We talk about globalisation in all aspects, and achieving a world-class standard as well. But for certain areas, should we have a second-tier service standard?  On this, I would like to applaud our leaders regarding our hawker centres.  If our hawker centres are privatised, I believe it is difficult for us to get a meal at $2.  So we need to make a choice.  If you wish to go to an air-conditioned hawker centre or a restaurant, you will need to pay $5 for a bowl of noodles. But if you go to a hawker centre that is without air-condition - you may even have to share the table with others and it is not possible to occupy one table by yourself - you will only have to pay $2.

Column: 1989


     Therefore, in this aspect, we may have to come to some form of consensus to see how we can coordinate with each other. In certain areas, we have to provide world-class services, so that the people are given a choice. But some other services may be of second-tier standard, for example, entertainment facilities for children.  Not every one can afford to go to Clarke Quay, Boat Quay or Marina South. In future, should we also have a second-tier type of entertainment facilities at Jurong Point, Ang Mo Kio Centre and Woodlands Point?


     On a last note, I am full of confidence for our Budget and our leaders.  I have many things to say but, due to time constraint, I will shorten my speech.  I believe that we are currently in the golden era, especially now that our economy is doing so well, we can use the very comfortable pace and logical mindset to think about it clearly.  We will have a clearer mind to analyse our future directions. Therefore, I feel that this is the best time to have an increase in GST rate and to revise our tax regime, as well as to carry out the WIS scheme.


     I fully support the Budget.

 

 

 

7.27 pm

 

     Mr Edwin Khew Teck Fook (Nominated Member): Mdm Deputy Speaker, may I first be allowed to wish all Members of this House and their families a very joyous and a successful Lunar New Year.

 

     Next, Madam, I would like to applaud the Second Minister for Finance for presenting what has been hailed by the business and manufacturing sectors as a pro-business and pro-SME budget.  And I believe, like the Minister, that this Budget will indeed help businesses and Singaporeans grow the economic pie and

Column: 1990

ensure the sustainable growth of Singapore over the next five to 10 years and beyond, taking advantage of globalisation.  More importantly, all are convinced that this is a serious Budget with long-term goals and strategies, compared to the stigma of last year's Budget which many touted as an election year Budget.

 

     Madam, I would like now to share with the House my findings from two feedback sessions organised last Thursday, 22nd and 23rd February with the Manufacturers Federation and the Singapore Business Federation. I would say the response from the manufacturers to attend the feedback sessions was quite poor.  So it was postponed because the Lunar New Year holidays were more important to them than the Budget.  But take it as a good sign.  It shows that the manufacturers in Singapore are happy with the Budget and the handful of written feedback SMA received indicated minor discomfort similar to feedback I received from approximately 100 companies and business representatives, mostly SMEs, who turned up at the SBF's conference room on Friday.  The SBF Secretariat staff and myself spent two hours listening and discussing about the Budget, after assessing from the outset that all present were generally happy with the Budget.

 

     Madam, please allow me now to summarise the issues raised.

 

 

Corporate tax

 

     It was suggested, to be consistent with the previous exemption ratio for corporate tax, that the Government should consider raising the 75% exemption level to the first $30,000 of chargeable income instead of $10,000.  The balance of $270,000 should then be at 50% exemption for year of assessment 2008. 

 

Column: 1991

Early enactment of Budget

 

     It was suggested that the Government look at enacting the Budget within six months of adoption, as this would be helpful to the business community in terms of obtaining clarity on specific changes.  The Income Tax Act 2007, for example, was gazetted on 13th February 2007, ie, almost one year after the 2006 Budget was passed. 

 

Definition and classification as SMEs

 

     It was suggested that the Government review the definition of SMEs, as currently companies with fixed assets of greater than S$15 million and employing more than 200 people do not qualify as SMEs.  In view of the Government's focus to grow SMEs and encourage SME start-ups, I would suggest that the Government look at redefining Singapore's definition of SMEs to align with more developed countries, if we want to attract these foreign SMEs to come to Singapore. 

 

     For example, the EU definition of a SME is an enterprise which employs fewer than 250 people and which has an annual turnover of less than 50 million Euros or approximately S$100 million and have a listed company that controls less than 25% of voting rights.  There are, of course, sub-divisions or categories of what is a small enterprise and what is a micro enterprise. 

 

     The Americans, on the other hand, have detailed definitions of what enterprises can qualify to be a small business.  They use a table of size standards which vary based on the industry sector the enterprise is in.  From the size standards chart of the US Small Business Administration, it looks like they define a SME as an enterprise either employing no more than 1,500 people or have a turnover of not more than US$28.5 million or approximately S$43 million, depending on the sector, type of

Column: 1992

industry and size standards of the industry.  For manufacturing, the size standard, for example, is based on the maximum of 500 employees.  So it looks like that the definition of a SME in the US depends on which size standard is being applied, ie, turnover or employee size. 

 

     Singapore needs to look at these major economic blocs and decide on which model we should follow or come up with our own hybrid, but a revised and updated definition is overdue, if we want to encourage foreign SMEs to come to Singapore and also Singapore SMEs to grow and to be on par with their foreign counterparts.  With the pro-SME Budget and incentives, I can see many Singapore SMEs being encouraged to explore joint ventures with European or US SMEs and vice versa.  I will elaborate later on on how I see this SME base growing, particularly in the manufacturing sector.

 

GST

 

     The sectors I represent seem comfortable with the one-step 2% increase in GST and the effective date of 1st July 2007.  A number, however, requested that the 50% grant to support GST registration related costs be processed speedily by the Government agencies, such as Spring, to help them on their cash flow.  There was also a request that the quota be increased to two representatives for GST registration related training courses organised by IRAS which, I believe, are free.  Many SME bosses feel that they need to attend together with their accountant as they are required to sign forms committing them to administer the GST, but they need to understand the requirements of what they will be committing to, in case their accountant leaves them. 

 

     There are three or four other issues regarding investment and capital allowances that I feel are not really related to the 2007 Budget Statement which I will

Column: 1993

bring up at other sittings.  However, Madam, I have one last issue regarding personal income tax.

 

     Many questioned why this was not addressed in line with the reduction of corporate tax, particularly when Singapore wants to attract highly qualified foreign talents to come to Singapore.  A reduction in personal income tax will further reinforce the key reasons for these talents to seriously consider Singapore and it will be on top of the advantages the Minister has mentioned in relation to why globalisation is working in Singapore's favour. 

 

     I am glad that the Minister does recognise that even though Singapore's personal tax rates are competitive, there are some other jurisdictions with lower effective tax rates compared to Singapore.  I, therefore, encourage the Minister to consider lowering our personal income tax rates to attract and keep both international and Singaporean talents in Singapore.

 

     Madam, I would like now to change gears and move on to another topic on the Budget Statement which I am passionate about.  I am referring to the growing of SMEs and, in particular, SMEs in manufacturing and the sector on sustainable energy.  Before I begin to discuss on this subject, I would like to declare my interest as the CEO and Managing Director of IUT Global Pte Ltd, a SME in the environment business generating renewable energy and biocompost from food waste.  IUT Global can therefore be considered a manufacturer and in the sustainable energy sector.  However, the comments I will be presenting on manufacturing and sustainable energy are made on the strengths of the two hats I wear as President of the Singapore Manufacturers' Association (SMA) and the Chairman of the

Column: 1994

Sustainable Energy Association of Singapore (SEAS).

 

     Madam, I would like the House now to refer to a diagram called Growing SME Manufacturing that I have circulated (copies of diagram distributed to hon. Members).  As seen from this diagram, for the manufacturing SME to be successful, it needs six elements, namely, IP/technology; money; markets; well-trained management, particularly the CEO and his senior managers; well-trained and highly-skilled workers; and research and development, which is optional, depending on the technology applied by the SME.  I have focused on the manufacturing SME because this is an area of SME development which I feel needs more support as it has the greatest potential to grow and succeed because of Singapore's manufacturing roots and the Singapore brand of manufactured products is well accepted today on a global basis.  More importantly, if we are successful in growing this sector, it will mean many jobs being created, including jobs for the PMETs and our mature workers, as each manufacturing SME will require a wide range of technical skills on the manufacturing or production floor, and also managerial skills, including marketing, branding, process management, human resource management, customer relationship management, finance, IP/technology management, etc.  In most cases, R&D and its management will be required only after successful start-up of the manufacturing process. 

 

     From the chart, we will see that in many branches of the six elements, both Government and the private sector need to work hand in hand.  The incentives provided by the Second Minister for Finance on tax exemption thresholds and reduction of corporate tax will go a long way to help SMEs grow.  But they do little to attract SMEs and start-ups to Singapore, as these tax benefits apply

Column: 1995

only for chargeable income when the SME becomes profitable.

 

     Madam, I am however encouraged and very optimistic about the Minister's intentions to make Singapore the best location for SMEs, local and foreign, to start, grow and globalise, and that he will continue to tweak the incentives to make it a no-brainer for foreign manufacturing SMEs from niche technologies, a sound business model and interested in the large East Asian market to look at setting up in Singapore.  After all, in Singapore, we already have strong IP laws, a highly skilled workforce who are disciplined and speak good English, plus we have good infrastructure, good living environment, stable Government, excellent healthcare services, educational institutions, R&D facilities, etc, all positive factors to make Singapore an attractive investment destination.

 

     Madam, may I now share with the House what the Singapore Manufacturers' Association is planning in the next two to three years to grow manufacturing in SMEs, both foreign and local, in Singapore. 

 

     Helping local entrepreneurs source for commercialisable IP.  The CEO of Nestle who serves on the ExCo in SMA as a Vice President is chairing SMA's SME Development Function Committee.  Nestle has a number of IPs that are commercialisable but it is not within their core business strategy to do so.  However, they are prepared to allow an entrepreneur to do so.  We know of a few other MNCs in the manufacturing sector which are also prepared to allow their IPs to be commercialised by third parties.  The Enterprise Development Centre (EDC) at SMA will work with Nestle and the SME Development Function Committee to find suitable entrepreneurs.  Good IP is very often a major consideration for start-ups.  The other major consideration is money.  I will elaborate on this later.

 

Column: 1996

     Attracting niche manufacturing SMEs from developed economies (DEs) to come to Singapore.  SMA is doing this in a number of ways:

 

     (1)  SMA is leading missions of local manufacturing SMEs to countries like the USA, Germany, Switzerland, Austria, Japan and Australia.  These missions will allow our SMEs to visit their counterparts in these developed economies where SME manufacturers are the backbone of their economy and employ a large percentage of their workforce.  It is hoped that this first contact will attract return missions from these developed economy SMEs and for these foreign SMEs to finally decide to come to Singapore.

 

     (2)  It is establishing official link-ups with these developed economy manufacturing associations.  SMA has already signed an MOU with the National Association of Manufacturers (NAM) in the US, and is in the process of doing likewise with the other developed economies.  Each of the local embassies of these six DEs identified by SMA is working very closely with SMA. 

 

    (3)  Providing technical training in SMA's workforce to the levels and standards expected of these developed economy SMEs.  SMA is working closely with WDA to extend SMA's already successful training centre, where upgrading of skills training is provided to all workers in the manufacturing sector, into a manufacturing institute.  This manufacturing institute will look at adopting course curriculum and standards currently used to qualify the workers required by all manufacturers, including the SMEs in these developed economies.  The manufacturing institute will also be introducing WSQ qualifications for the manufacturing sector currently being designed by WDA.  This will be another pull factor for these SME manufacturers to choose Singapore, as they know the qualification of our workers will meet their standards.

 

Column: 1997

     Finally, tapping markets globally for SMEs.  The six MOUs with manufacturing associations in the developed economies will represent market opportunities.  SMA has also established relationships with many manufacturing associations in regional countries like China, India, Malaysia, Thailand, etc, and helping countries like Vietnam establish their own manufacturing associations.  SMA will continue to work closely with IE Singapore and also with many of our members who have established manufacturing presence all over the world, including new frontiers like Russia, Kazakhstan and the Middle East, to ensure markets in these countries are open to our Singapore manufacturers.

 

 

    Madam, what is missing from my presentation above is money or funds to help the SMEs start up or expand. I know a number of my colleagues in this House, including Mr Inderjit Singh, had brought up the subject of an SME bank.  I would like to request that the Minister considers this issue seriously as even with the best plans by SMA and even with Spring, to encourage the start-up and growth of SMEs, if money not enough, then Singapore will have "SMEs no enough."  Perhaps Jack Neo can produce a sequel of his "no enough" movies to show that SMEs can start up and grow in Singapore. Many of our commercial banks in Singapore provide loans based on commercial terms and standard commercial risks which do not factor in the higher risk profile of start-ups or low-asset profile of these SME start-ups. These SMEs, looking to start up or grow, will therefore not meet the collateral requirements of these banks. 

 

    Madam, my last topic is sustainable energy and how Singapore can grow SMEs in this sector, making Singapore a de facto centre of excellence for the whole value chain of this new but highly

Column: 1998

scaleable business.  I am heartened that the Minister did mention alternative energy in his Budget Statement and that Singapore will seek to participate in this emerging industry.  May I strongly suggest to the Minister that Singapore is currently in the best position to develop into an Asian centre for sustainable energy or alternative energy or clean energy which all mean nearly the same thing except that sustainable energy also includes energy efficiency. 

 

    Except for Japan and Korea, there are no structured programmes in any country in East Asia similar to the strategy I am proposing for Singapore to take the regional leadership position in this sector. The fact that a number of leading foreign solar companies like Conergy, Solar World, Solar Fabric and, more recently, Phoenix Solar have based their Asian HQ in Singapore should be a strong signal that Singapore has all the pre-requisites to attract these companies to come here.  I am of the opinion that Singapore can do more so that we can take the momentum already generated by these major companies on solar energy to extend this to other technology providers in a sustainable energy sector, for example, wind, bio-mass, bio-gas, thermal, geothermal, fuel cells, bio-fuel, hydro, wave, river current, etc.  The Minister has identified an alternative energy market size of US$300 billion by 2015.  And I dare say that most of these is in Asia alone as 80% of the world's alternative energy projects are projected to be in Asia.

 

     Madam, I would like now to refer the House to my second diagram which will help illustrate the tremendous value chain associated with this business which will include project financing, project development, project engineering and management, technology providers, clothing manufacturers and suppliers of systems, energy service companies or ESCOs, R&D and carbon or emission

Column: 1999

trading.  Each of these areas of specialisation will bring foreign talent and will develop local talent at all levels. 

 

    Madam, the Second Minister for Finance and also our Minister Mentor, Prime Minister and the Minister for National Development in the media, have all painted a picture of a cleaner and greener Singapore.  We must have a living environment that is the "best" in Asia.  We will make Singapore a city of "Gardens and Waters", a city of "Green and Blue".

 

    Many Members of this House have also spoken yesterday and today on the need for Singapore to be environmentally-sustainable and for Singapore to demonstrate how seriously we can take climate change. Madam, I support strongly the direction that all Ministers and my fellow MPs are taking and would like to especially applaud our Minister Mentor for being the great architect who has, as early as 1965, forged the clean and green agenda for Singapore.  I would like, however, for Singapore to take one step further to not only be the cleanest and greenest city in the world, but also the most environmentally-sustainable city in the world. What this means is that, besides being aesthetically clean and green, we need to:

 

   (1)  Be the most energy-efficient city in the world. 

 

   (2)  Have the most environmentally-friendly industries in the world.  I would like to see all industries and manufacturers adopt ISO 14000 or an improved environmental management system or EMS programme.  

 

    (3)  Have the cleanest air in the world.  Our Government may need to legislate on PM 2.5 and mandate the use of cleaner fuels and bio-fuels for our transport sector; and

 

Column: 2000

    (4)  Emit the lowest CO2 per capita in the world. 

 

     Singapore can be a great model sustainable city, not only for Asia but the rest of the world, providing all solutions to assist our neighbours in the region to avert global warming and problems with climate change.  I am confident that as a centre for sustainable energy, Singapore will achieve three of the four points that I have mentioned above and be a model city at the same time. 

 

   Madam, I would like now to share with the House an email I received from an investment banker based in Hong Kong.  I asked him a very simple question:  how can Singapore attract you to come here?  He said:

 

      "To move my company to Singapore includes a lot of change not only for me but also for my family, including change of social network, doctor, schools, favourite restaurants, shopping, etc. So there is a lot of inertia and challenges for the whole family built into such a move.  Singapore has good schools, housing, healthcare, etc, but so has Hong Kong, Bangkok, etc, and the differences are well-known and have been discussed several times in both companies and families.  To trigger a change would be a new factor such as environment and air pollution. And the trigger would be for Singapore to step up and take a leadership position amongst cities in Asia and globally in terms of addressing these issues. For example, if Singapore Government introduced not a 2% to 5% lending target by 2012, but something much bolder, such as 20% or 50% lending target by 2010, that will make headlines and profile Singapore to the general public and amongst corporates and families around Asia and globally.  My son would then come running to me and say, "Now we need to move to Singapore there." 

 

    Lee Kuan Yew recently made a statement that Singapore has reached the top group of countries and cities globally

Column: 2001

and now need to move from the bottom of that group to the top of the group. The way to achieve this is to do what countries like Germany and Scandinavian countries have done - make bold steps and be a leader in the environmental regulation and you will find that the feared negative impact on the economy is compensated by a whole set of new enterprises and jobs created from industries developed to deal with the new regulations, and being a leader globally means that these new industries become global leaders. So I am not asking for tax holidays, better housing, etc, but a more global and general response in order to convince the rest of my family. 

 

    Living in Hong Kong, we are already sick of the air pollution and the government's inability and lack of courage to deal with basic issues.  Buses on clean bio-diesel scramble for our power plants, etc. Singapore has a great chance to differentiate itself on this point by showing courage and taking bold steps.  Edwin, in short, I will bring my business to Singapore when your Government takes a lead role and bold steps on air pollution."

 

    This is one view from an investment banker.  Madam, I would therefore conclude and suggest that the Second Minister for Finance and the Government consider setting up a central agency to facilitate and promote Singapore as this centre for sustainable energy. At the moment, although there is a combined committee from all Ministries looking into this sector, I would implore the Government to set up a central agency with some teeth to spearhead and to come up with policies that can help facilitate foreign SMEs who are funders or technology providers in this sector to start

Column: 2002

up in Singapore.  The central agency should be able to facilitate and assist on all areas to do with incentives, test-bedding technologies, setting up of semi-commercial or full commercial renewable energy systems, feeding in policies on renewable energy to the grid, including perhaps mandatory percentage of renewable energy in utility mix, setting up of a sustainable energy fund with some base funding from the Government, etc. 

 

    Madam, Singapore needs to act now before we lose the chance to build up a leadership position.  As Mr Lim Swee Say has just quoted, Singapore is small, but we need to be fast to survive.  I do urge us to be fast to seize the opportunities I have just proposed.

 

   Madam, I support the motion.

GOVERNMENT SCHOLARS EMPLOYED BY CIVIL SERVICE

(Career paths and development roadmaps)

     6.   Ms Denise Phua Lay Peng asked the Prime Minister and Minister for Finance (a) what is the number of Government scholars currently employed by the Civil Service; (b) what are their career paths and development roadmaps; and (c) how will their development roadmaps prepare them adequately for the many important tasks they are assigned to.

     Mr Teo Chee Hean:

     Each year, the Public Service Commission (PSC) offers about 40-50 scholarships to top students(1). These scholars pursue their undergraduate studies in top local and overseas universities. The majority of them are on "Open" scholarships and will return from their studies to work in various Ministries and Government agencies. A small number will be deployed to the Ministries of Education, Law and Foreign Service to pursue more specialised career paths. These scholars are groomed to take on top leadership roles.

 

     In addition, the Ministries also award about 150 Ministry scholarships each year to serve the need for talent in the respective Ministries.

 

     There are currently about 2,000 PSC and Ministry scholarship holders in the Civil Service.  Slightly more than half are in the teaching service. If we exclude the teachers, one out of every 10 graduate civil servants is a beneficiary of a Government scholarship.

 

     To prepare the scholars for their role, the Service invests substantially in their development. We seek to give our scholars a rounded exposure to our national challenges and issues. Scholars attend programmes at different points of their student life - before they embark on their studies, midway through their studies and upon return. We offer them challenging assignments and opportunities to stretch themselves in various roles. All scholars are required to participate in community attachment programmes during their student days(2) so that they have a better understanding of the concerns and issues faced by Singaporeans. 

 

     The development roadmap for the scholars varies with the inclination and strength of each individual. For scholars who have the capacity to assume top leadership positions, they will be groomed and better prepared for these roles through planned postings and leadership programmes. For those who have the aptitude to take on more specialist functions, the Ministries will provide the necessary training and exposure to develop their capabilities in their selected fields.

 

     Besides the PSC and Ministry scholarships, Statutory Boards like A*Star, EDB and DSTA also award about 170 scholarships each year to meet their own manpower needs. These scholars are managed by their parent organisations directly.

Developmental roadmap for tied scholars after they have started work

Management Associates are selected for their potential to be appointed to the Administrative Service (AS). Administrative Officers from the AS form the majority of the leadership tier in the Civil Service, thus their career paths and development roadmaps are designed in a way to give them a broad exposure to not just policy-making and strategy, but also to implementation and operation. They are deliberately given a broad range of postings across different clusters of ministries, and even postings outside the Civil Service. Postings may vary from between two and five years, depending on their seniority.

ACCIDENTS INVOLVING MOTORCYCLISTS, BICYCLISTS AND PEDESTRIANS

     12.   Ms Ellen Lee asked the Deputy Prime Minister and Minister for Home Affairs in view of the increase in the number of vehicles and fatal accident cases (a) what is the number of accidents involving bicyclists and motorcyclists for 2006; (b) how many of the motorcyclists in these accidents were newly qualified; (c) what measures have the Traffic Police taken against these motorcyclists apart from prosecution, composition fines and demerit points; (d) how many licences have been revoked and reinstated in 2006; (e) what is the number of accidents involving pedestrians and bicyclists in 2006; (f) what actions have been taken against the bicyclists and errant pedestrians; and (g) what measures have the Traffic Police taken to protect the safety of pedestrians and bicyclists.

     Mr Wong Kan Seng:

     Motorcyclists

 

     In 2006, there were 4,300 accidents(4)  involving motorcyclists of which 740 accidents(5) or 17% involved motorcyclists who were newly qualified and still on the 12-month probation period after obtaining their licence. Motorcyclists remain the most vulnerable group of road users, accounting for 48%(6), or almost half, of all road fatalities in 2006. The main cause of these accidents is speeding.

    44 motorcyclist licences were revoked on medical grounds and under the New Driver Rules. In addition, 10 licences were suspended under the Driver Improvement Point System (DIPs) for 12 months or more and 1,050 motorcyclist licences were disqualified by the Courts for 12 months or more.

 

     A licence revoked on medical grounds will be reinstated if the licence holder produces a medical certificate to prove his fitness or ability to drive. Last year, no licence revoked on medical grounds was reinstated by Traffic Police. The period of revocation under the new driver rules is one year, after which the person has to pass the prescribed tests of competency, both theory and practical, to obtain a new licence.

 

     Besides enforcement, Traffic Police mounts public education programmes that target motorcyclists. Indeed, TP plans to do more to instil greater road safety awareness in newly-qualified motorcyclists. In April this year, TP will present a new Road Safety package for riders developed in collaboration with motorcycle clubs associated with the

Column: 2015

Singapore Bikers Forum at the Global Road Safety Week launch. Adopting the approach of "road safety education for motorcyclists by motorcyclists", TP will work closely with them to give road safety talks to students in ITEs and polytechnics.

 

Cyclists

 

     As for cyclists and pedestrians, two other vulnerable groups of road users, last year, there were 510 accidents(7) involving cyclists. 480 summonses were issued, of which 210 summonses or 43%(8) were for failing to ride in an orderly manner. For cases where cyclists have knocked into pedestrians, especially on pavements, investigation will be carried out under the Penal Code for offences of rash or negligent act or causing hurt by rash or negligent act.

 

     Traffic Police has introduced several safety education measures for cyclists.  These include a Bicycle Training Course at South West CDC's Community Resilience Carnival in February last year which imparted safe cycling knowledge through practical training to some 1,000 participants.

 

Pedestrians

 

     As for pedestrians, there were 910 accidents(9) last year. Traffic Police issued 6,970 summonses to pedestrians last year, of which about 56% were for failure to conform to the traffic signal at pedestrian crossings.

 

     Pedestrians remain the second most vulnerable group of road users last year, after motorcyclists. The number of pedestrians killed accounted for 22% of total fatalities. Traffic Police has introduced several measures and initiatives to reach out to pedestrians, in particular vulnerable groups like the elderly and young children.

 

     For senior citizens, Traffic Police has distributed 10,000 handy bags carrying the road safety message: “Be Seen, Be Safe, Walk Bright” to senior citizens through a series of CSSP activities and road safety talks.  The good news is that the number of elderly pedestrians killed in road accidents last year dropped by 40%.

 

     For young children below the age of 12, Traffic Police, in collaboration with DaimlerChrysler, reached out to 12 schools through the Mobilekids programme in 2006. Through this programme, children and youth learn about road safety in an engaging and fun-filled theme park, right in the compound of their schools. TP plans to take this programme to more schools this year.

 

Conclusion

 

     Most road accidents can be prevented if road users exercise more care, caution and consideration at all times. I take this opportunity to remind all who use our roads, whether as motorists, motorcyclists, bicyclists or pedestrians, to embrace a safety-conscious and courteous mindset every time they share this critical common space.

'THROUGH-TRAIN' STUDENTS

(Performance and objectives)

     14.   Mr Christopher de Souza asked the Minister for Education (a) if he will provide data on how 'through-train' students of the current cohort are performing in their A level course as compared to students who did their O levels, the comparison being based on students who had similar PSLE results; (b) what was the rationale for introducing 'through-train'; and (c) whether its objectives are being met.

     Mr Tharman Shanmugaratnam:

          The first batch of ‘through-train’ or Integrated Programme students who joined the programme at Secondary 3 in 2004 will be taking their A-levels or the International Baccalaureate examinations at the end of this year. So we are unable to compare their performance with the rest of their peers as yet.

 

     Mr de Souza asked about the rationale for the Integrated Programme (IP). As outlined in the 2002 Review of Junior College and Upper Secondary education, the IP aims to provide a broad-based education that cultivates in our top students the qualities that will help them make a difference in work and life. It seeks to nurture intellectual curiosity, leadership, teamwork and communication skills and, most importantly, sound values.

 

     The IP schools have been using the time freed up from not having to prepare for the O-levels by providing their students with broader and deeper learning experiences, such as through independent research, seminars, fieldwork, expeditions and overseas immersions. For example, Raffles Institution’s Research Education programme allows students to engage extensively with external experts, develop their own research skills as well as learn life skills as “apprentices” in an authentic research environment. One student spent two years studying distribution patterns of marine snails under guidance from NUH experts.  He won the best presentation award at the SEAMEO(10) Young Scientists’ Conference last year, and will continue his research this year.

 

     Overall, the IP schools are moving in the right direction. A full assessment of whether the programme has achieved its objectives can only be made further down the road, after the students complete their studies and become active members of society. It is also relatively new in our school system, and we should give the different IP schools and programmes time to develop and to grow distinctive features.
